The only way it wouldn't be more economical to park on your own is if you will need multiple in/out privileges; you have to pay each time you leave the garage.Overall a great hotel that you should have few, if any, qualms about booking. We'll definitely stay at The Blackwell again.My first stay at The Blackwell was pleasant. The staff was professional and I was greeted promptly. Our room was relatively spacious complete with cable TV, a marble bathroom and decent sheets. I woke up to a USA today at my door which is always a nice touch. The lobby was decorated for Christmas and very pretty. They went a little too far with a cinnamon scent, they really don't need it and it gave me a headache.The banquet meal was good. What you would expect from a hotel. I'm rounding up a 3.5 star to a 4. The hotel met my expectations and I applaud the students who run it. They are doing a great job operationally but at the end of the day this is a business hotel, it is not the Ritz Carlton.I've stayed here during two visits to THE Ohio State University. The Blackwell is an amazing hotel, and I'm flabbergasted that students of the Fisher School of Business can run an establishment like this so professionally. Check-in:The door is opened for you with a smile and greeting. A comfy lobby greets you, with a seating area and stairs in the center. To the left, the check-in desk and gift shop; to the right, the bar and lounge with a wonderful fireplace and big TVs. The front desk attendants are very friendly and efficient. I request a "no-post" (no hold on debit card) on my room and they are happy to comply. I get my key and head up in the elevator.The Room:Both visits, I've stayed in a Double room with Queen Size beds. The rooms are very large and well-appointed. They feature ultra-comfy beds with lots of pillows and a down comforter. The window offers a great view of THE Ohio State football stadium and other recognizable buildings. My favorite feature of the rooms has been the large built-in desks, with power outlets built in to the surface. I have plenty of room to spread out all of my papers and computer peripherals. Between the desks is a very large flat-panel television that serves as the centerpiece of the room. The bathrooms are clean and fairly large. I always enjoy the showers with adjustable showerheads, and the large bathtub. The food:Excellent!! I had several meals during the most recent event that brought me to The Blackwell. Most memorably, a catered dinner that featured a huge spread; salad, prosciutto and asparagus trays, portobello mushroom ravioli, garlic bread, squash, steaks, and some *incredible* stuffed chicken breasts. I returned for seconds. The Blackwell is an awesome concept, and I applaud Fisher and its students for doing such an amazing job. If I'm ever in Columbus again, I know where I'm staying!The hotel, itself, was above average. Rooms were clean and comfortable, and the hotel was easy to navigate. We met at the Conference Center next to the hotel, which was great for the purposes of our meeting. One large meeting room with breakout rooms nearby. The setup was just perfect for my company's retreat. I wouldn't hesitate to stay there again.The staff went above and beyond, helping me coordinate my stay and get little things accomplished. The shuttle from the airport is great, runs about ever 90 minutes, just have to call ahead. A pretty good setup to avoid renting a car if OSU is the focus of your stay. Everyone I worked with was friendly and professional.Free HBO! A block away from THE Ohio State Football stadium! Near campus! Near Hide Street (good collection of restaurants and the like)The rooms were comfortable, with a well stocked restroom and closet. The business center has free internet. The Bistro wasn't too bad either. Room service came by frequently and checked to ensure that we were in good shape for services.Definitely not a bad place to stay when you are snowed in, like I was during my trip to THE Ohio State Grad program
review_content_40: Expect to catch a bite before the 3pm checkin to your room.  Don't.  I should have eaten at the airport. Hanging around for 3 hours to get a room.blackwell is the hotel that you root forit's the independent bookstore next to b&nit's the immaculate caffeination next to starbucksthe rooms are nice, they are trying so very hard, but sometimes, you wonder why they don't quite have their act together

hotel_name: Sheraton Columbus Hotel at Capitol Square
review_content: Nice, city hotel.  We were in town for the weekend and this one looked like I'd expect from Sheraton and we got what we expected.  Front desk staff was pleasant and seems genuinely sorry for a room key error, so it was not big deal.  Room was decently sized and very clean.  We stayed club level and the club suite had everything we needed and very friendly staff.  We didn't eat at the restaurant and the street level Starbuck's is just a Starbuck's.  Nothing special about it.  My one issue with the place isn't really even their fault - parking.  As a lot of yelpers have written, the valet is extremely slow in retrieving your vehicle.  I realize due to location of the cars, the traffic, and the one way streets, it takes time.  At $28 or whatever it is, it's certainly not worth it.  You can park across the street for $17 a day and have your car in 2 minutes.  The valets also won't let you use the luggage carts without them taking them to the room.  It didn't bother me too much and our guy was very friendly and helpful, so that's a positive. Overall, a nice, clean hotel with good views and one I would return too.I liked the location but I didn't like the fact that when I left the hotel I couldn't come back until the evening because I only had 1 free valet per day.  I looked at their room service and noticed the 22% gratuity and thought it was a little excessive.  Plus I never meet anybody from the conference I went to which sucked. Plus why was every restaurant around the State Capitol closed after 10pm during the week day? I thought a bigger city would be a little more liberal on that front.  I came to this hotel in July.  I found it annoying that they had no premium channels.  I did get this hotel at a really cheap rate ($99) which was nice.This Sheraton was real nice and centrally located in DT C-bus. We dida last minute booking (same evening) & scored an amazing "name your own price" deal. Even considering the 3rd party , reduced-rate booking type, they still awarded my SPG points and perks for a nicer room & free H2O btl. The lobby is very modern and pretty. All facilities we saw were clean and room much updated and spacious! Staff was very friendly and professional. Would definitely stay here again and also recommend.Nice hotel, friendly staff and very comfortable beds but the worst shower I've ever experienced!  Water just randomly changes from warm to scalding hot to cold and then stays cold. Bathroom dusty and not very clean.Everytime I stay at a Sheraton Hotel I'm always impressed with the customer service and attention to detail used in there design of the lobby and guest rooms. I suggest becoming a Sheraton club member because you always get the automatic upgrades and added perks during your stay. This Sheraton had a Starbucks in the lobby that was top notch and made the stay that much more enjoyable. The restaurant was 5 star and top shelf drinks and entrees. Try the steak nasal lions and spiced vegetables. Truly amazing in every way. I recommend staying here even if it's out of the way. Well worth a try!! :)This review is for the Sheraton as an event location, not for the hotel itself.Sweetie and I came for the Ohioana book festival, held in several banquet rooms here.  It was a good place for such an event- plenty of room and amenities, clean, easy to find and get around.  Parking is right across the street at the Statehouse.  Columbus Commons is right nearby if you're going to an event there.  The lobby has comfy chairs and some working areas, plus a Starbucks.For a conference, trade show, wedding, etc., this would be a nice facility in a prime location.Attended the Columbus Arts festival last weekend and the Sheraton, which we found out is the official hotel of the festival, helped us out in a last minute pinch, when the property we originally booked had a water main break & cancelled all reservations.We were graciously welcomed when we dropped off our cars and walked in the lobby to check in, the check in process took minutes and we were on our way.Our room on the 10th floor was clean, AC worked well, bed was comfortable, got a restful nights sleep. Only qualm was the bed & bathroom linens were pretty warn, yes they do get lots of use in a big hotel, but could have been newer, better quality.Stayed here for a wedding weekend.  The staff was very friendly and helpful.  The valet parking is a bit steep but it's not hard to find spots on the street or in nearby lots on the weekend.We had a lovely view of the Statehouse from our room.Keep in mind the Starbucks located in the hotel has limited hours and the adjacent retail shops and restaurants were closed on Saturday.We did not eat in the hotel so can't speak to the food quality.  Just a few minutes drive to plenty of eateries and attractions.Good place to stay while visiting Columbus for a business trip. Amenities are average and I wouldn't say there was anything special about this place. I was impressed that they had siggis yogurt at their catered breakfast. That's my favorite yogurt!While I believe this may be on of the nicer starwood properties downtown, there are a few other properties in general that are a tad bit nicer. So why do I stay at this location:(1) Overall, the staff is excellent. Sometimes their desire to be friendly causes slow check-ins, but when it is your turn, you don't mind so much.(2) This property has a club level and I usually take advantage of breakfast and or appetizers in the evening if I make it back in time.(3) Location as others have been mentioned is pretty decent and when the weather is nice makes for a nice walk into more populated areas of the city.On the other hand, this hotel really can go from good to great with some slight finishing touches (updated bathroom fixtures, decor, better gym design). Oh how I wish they would, but it's not enough to keep me away.Our alumni association recently held its Hall of Fame reception and ceremony at the Sheraton Capitol Square.  This review does not cover individual rooms, guest services or bar/restaurant.I worked directly with room, catering and A/V services.  They are a very buttoned-up group from start to finish.  Mine was a relatively small group (130 guests) so 2/3 of the Governor's ballroom became our choice.  We held the reception in the lobby area outside the ballroom then opened the doors to seating (15 ten-round tables) with speaker's riser, two podiums with mics, one handheld mic for audience participation, screen and projector for powerpoint presentation.Everyone was great to work with on the project.  We enjoyed butler-passed foods, had cash bar service and a veggie, cheese and crackers table for attendees.  The catering staff put together the menu (standard but delicious, coconut baked shrimp, chicken, and other nice warm foods).  Each time I requested a table or chair set-up it was done.  The A/V team knew answers to things when we asked them.A couple notes.  Elevators to that area were difficult to locate and we needed on for a 92-year old attendee.  The valet car-park area is very tight.  The staff hustles but on a busy evening my bet would be on the time clock running awhile before your car appears.  Congested.Location, location, location..... the Sheraton Capitol Square also served as one of our company's clients for the 2013 Presidents Cup.  With Columbus Commons being an adjacent site, this is very convenient and very nice view.I'll take groups back to the Sheraton Capitol Square.  Yes!Worst place I've ever stayed in. The HVAC was loud all day and night, and they didn't change my comforter.. I was there for 3 nights! I realized in horror the last morning. Didn't even have HBO or Showtime smh. Don't book it.When I search for a hotel in a moderate sized city and immediately see the "Call" word next to just about every option, I get worried. I get worried that I'll have to either pay a) an exhorbitant amount of money for an even "decent" hotel room - if said room is even available or 2) I'll have to stay miles and miles outside of the city center in a random motel. No thanks.Thus, I wasn't thrilled paying $280/night for this hotel stay during my last trip to Cbus, but I truly didn't have any other nearby option. Let's roll down the pros and cons...The Good:-Starbucks in the lobby-Friendly staff-Comfy beds and nicely appointed rooms-Modern decor-Choice toiletries that include shave cream, shampoo/condo, body wash, lotion, mini shower loofah, nail kit, mouth wash, soap-Keurig in room-Club rooms are spacious and offer a nice for additional snacks and continental breakfast food-Jeni's ice cream available in the lobby coolerThe Meh:-That price was craaaaazy-Location is decent but facing a busy street so grabbing a ride of any kind can be on the challenging side -Elevators are on the slow side-Room service options are lackluster at bestWhile this wouldn't be my first choice for a Columbus hotel, it provided the necessary means for a comfortable night's stay.This is, by far, one of the best options for Downtown business hotel!Large modern rooms and hallways.  Great linens.  Nice furniture in rooms. Towels are good.  Bed is very comfy.  Alarm clock is great quality.The second floor has a large and comfortable lounge and dining area - I love it!I always got my coffee off-site from here...Location:On MON/TUE catch the happy hour sushi specials down the street at Rishi Sushi Kitchen & Bar.On WED/THU, at 7:30, catch a $4 movie at the absolutely beautiful Ohio theatre - this is on the same block - this is a MUST DO.For coffee/ breakfast/ lunch, go to Au Bon Pain - it is 1/2 block away, or Tim Hortons a bit further, or if you are really -SERIOUS- about your coffee, go to Cafe Brioso.For cocktails or a bite to eat, go to Gay street - tip top - 2 blocks away - just a bit further than Au Bon Pain.Or go to the establishments across from the Greyhouse station - El Camino Inn is one of them,For dinner - well, I haven't found anything -great- yet, so keep looking.Columbus has a lot of cocktail bars with good prices, and multi-level parking garages.Nice hotel, very clean and the staff was extremely friendly and helpful. The gym is on the 22nd floor and has an awesome view of downtown the 2nd floor bar has decent food and friendly bartenders.  It's probably not the best deal in town price-wise but I wanted a location that was walkable to all the places I needed to get to.  Besides 'overpriced' in Ohio is still cheaper the 90% of most other places.My only complaint was the lack of a vent/fan in the bathroom, luckily my sht doesn't stink but you're probably not as fortunate.Like others have mentioned...the beds are comfy, the rooms are spacious and the location is in the smack dab center of the city.  And the refurbishments are nice.  So that is all good.The lounge sucks.  Well actually the service sucks and the food sucks, the lounge itself is decent.The staff totally blows.  The front desk is a bit surly.  I don't know if they have more than one luggage cart, but if they do, they are missing.  They have a bellhop who will "put your name on the list" to come get your crap but how about just having more carts....?  The valet guys are nice, but get your name on that list too because it takes a while.  They like to charge for everything.  $10/day for crappy internet, $23/day for valet, $10 for a fridge.  Sorry, but if I am here for 2 weeks, you can probably throw a few of those things in.Also the housekeeping is terrible.So yeah, it sucks.Nice hotel. Very clean and with in walking distance to many of Columbus' top attractions. The wifi isn't the quickest, but it isn't too bad and very usable. The bathrooms are large and the beds are comfortable. I'm disappointed in their resturaunt. It's pretty terrible even for a hotel resturaunt. But there's a full Starbucks in the lobby. Coffee lovers, drink your heart out!My review is for the restaurant only. We stopped in because it was close to the theatre and the rolling rain storms are not kind to dress clothes.We were seated by the hostess whom we told we were stopping for a drink and dessert before a show at the Ohio. We waiting ten minutes before the bartender  noticed no waitress had servers us and took our drink order. We waited another ten minutes before flagging down our "server" (whom only stopped by to refill the water the bartender provided us) to order our dessert.The bartender poured generously on the glass of port wine I ordered. The dessert ordered was fine (it was a brulee, but it was really cold as if it wasn't torched fresh).On our way out we passed a sad looking wine cabinet that only had two bottles in it. The rest of the restaurant seemed nice, but more as a bar to cater to the hotel guests, and not the fine dining experience they were trying to make it out to be. It was pretty darkly lit as well, matching the drab rainy day outside. It's also confusing to have to take a roundabout escalator or elevators to reach the restaurant itself.The dessert and drink was acceptable. The neglectful service was not. I will not be returning with other fine dining options well within walking distance.Great, comfortable room.  Good view of downtown.  Perfect place to end an evening after dinner at De Novo and a drink at Sidebar.  Oh, and a bellman who looked like Ryan Johansen.  He said he gets that a bit.The rooms were pretty decent. The bed was comfortable and the room was clean. The shower takes about 10 minutes to get past lukewarm. The coffee provided in the room was Starbucks which was nice. The coffeemaker was kind of messy though because the individual coffee pods were too big for the holder. The bar/restaurant lounge on the 2nd floor was nice. We didn't grab food there but it was comfortable. There were a couple of televisions playing the football games. The bartender was extremely nice. There was a loud, obnoxious group of people at a table behind us so we chose to leave. It rained the night we were there so we didn't venture too far by foot but there are a few bars within walking distance. The valet the night we were there deserves about 1 star. It is $25 for overnight and we waited for 10 minutes on the street before we could even pull into the drive. When we finally got to pull in, there were still a bunch of cars and 2 valet attendants standing there socializing. I don't know if the attendants need to go, or the valet area needs to be larger.
review_content_20: Staying here for two weeks on business trip. It's a fine hotel, but certainly not worth the money. Not a value. I would recommend staying elsewhere for this price. Friendly staff, good location, and clean premises. However, the decor is very dated. Popcorn ceilings, dark brown wallpaper and carpet, and black furniture. Very dark rooms regardless of windows.  There aren't sufficient power plugs. So, if you are planning on bringing a few devices, like a phone, computer, etc. bring a multi-outlet adapter. The AC is amped up - very cold!  Even after turning off air or turning on heat (which doesn't work in summer) it is extremely cold. If you visit during the summer pack sweaters and warm pajamas. Our toilet was running (because it's really old, the ones they used to make in the 80's before water efficient toilets were mandated by law) and on the third day actually flooded out the bathroom (not from it being plugged up nor from debris). They were very accommodating and prompt to help us move to another room. Again, very polite and kind staff. But we had a lot of stuff to move, as we are here for two weeks. It was an inconvenience. The toilet in the new room also runs, which is noisy and annoying, but hasn't overflown yet. I think this must have been a really amazing hotel back in 1980, but unfortunately it still feels like the 80's in here. On the website, it says it was established in 2011, but it seems like that might be when Sheraton bought it from another hotel company, because this hotel and decor is certainly much older than that. Again, it's an average hotel with nice staff, but certainly not worth the money.Exemplary ServiceThis was the most consistent A+ service throughout. The check-in desk staff all had bright smiles. The server in the lounge had a smile and was friendly. The room service was discrete and observant (left extra shower gel without being asked). The Club Floor rooms were great and I loved the upgraded elements. All around A+ for the service and attitude for the employees. Would definitely recommend again.First, let me say the beds are sooo comfortable. The rooms are spacious, but could be better lit. We had a decent rate, so I don't think it's all that overpriced.Here are a few tips for making the most of your stay here:* We chose this hotel in part because of the shuttle, which we needed for transport to the convention center. However, the hours the shuttle runs are very, very limited - something like 7 to 10 a.m. and 4 to 7 p.m. Weekdays only. The shuttle driver is very nice, however, and even started his day a little early for us. * We ordered in-room breakfast and specified two people. The first day it arrived late with service  items for one person (we ordered two items and wrote in the number of persons).* The yogurt parfait has a ton of jam in it. If you're okay with this, it's huge and will fill you right up. Happy to see someone posted a photo - check it out before you order.* Housekeeping will not change the sheets if you leave anything on the bed, including pajamas. We found this out the hard way. The next day, we made a point of clearing the beds of non-hotel items; they were made, but no clean sheets (this was on our 3rd day). The next morning we left a note explicitly requesting a change, and, ta-da, fresh sheets at last!* The bathroom was generally clean, with the exception of a little mold at the bottom of the shower curtain. * Beware of the hotel glasses. The ones in the bathroom had a layer of toothpaste (not ours) at the bottom. Instead, use the disposable cups. Pro tip!* The WiFi here is *painfully* slow! Also, it costs $10/day; should be free. * On the plus side, there is a beautiful park just behind the hotel with a Neo electronic playground. There was even live music playing there on Friday night. The Starbucks in the lobby is also quite nice. Also, they provide free bottled water in the rooms.Good location for a hotel. However, it was the second highest priced room I could find in the city, and yet they charge $25 for valet on top of room price and only provide parking in an adjacent building where you get charged by the hour.  Furthermore, I am visiting for Columbus pride; came to the room at 3 am and just wanted to order room service. The menu is lackluster (reminiscent of airline snack for purchase food), and when I called to place an order I was informed that they were not serving food tonight of all nights even though the menu says 12am to 6am everyday. They couldn't even recommend a restaurant that would deliver.Oh, final note: there is no vent in the bathroom. So if you go for number 2, bring some deodorizer. Overall, this has been a pretty bad experience for the price I paid. I Will choose a cheaper motel next time and will probably have similar or better amenities and service.One of the worst hotel stays we've ever had! We still had fun in Columbus because we know in the grand scheme of things, these are not "real problems" Life is too short to care about petty things.  However, given we were in an American city staying in a well-known chain hotel with the amount of money we spent each night, we expected to have a smooth stay.What worked?-The valet guys were on the ball! Professional, prompt and good-humored-Large comfortable king-sized bed-Room service delivery was timely and the food was well-prepared What didn't work?-Room was dark and stuffy-Lame excuses and inexplicable passive-aggressive/weird behavior. Examples:-Had to put our dining trays outside after wait staff was no show when we called down -We came in around 3am after attending the High Ball halloween festival. It was late but we were not loud. We were undressing and watching videos online. Perhaps we were louder than we thought we were, but I believe the walls are pretty thin. Security came up to warn us that we were disturbing other guests...by laughing in bed. Hmmm-At one point, in the middle of the night, someone tried to enter our room. My boyfriend went to the door and no one was there. He lingered and a hotel employee came around the corner. When my bf asked if it was him who tried to open the door, after a series of incomplete, indirect answers, he finally said yes they were making the rounds. But couldn't really explain why he was trying to open our door.  -When we called down to front desk to see if we could get a couple of bananas before a run, a man told us that it would cost $25.00 to enter the "platinum member" restaurant and how allowing us to buy two bananas would not be "fair" to those members. Hmmm. Then when we asked if there was a local store we could go to, he said he didn't have any idea where we could go in the area.-When we called downstairs  for service regarding the cable, we were told to look around our room for the TV guide. I promptly told the woman that I already did that  (thats why I was calling). Then she put me on hold and transferred me to the hotel bar where another employee said to go to "channel 300" and if I was still having issues, he'd send up "hotel engineers." There are not 300 channels! It was clear they were taking a piss and had no interest in helping us. When we called back, they said they would come up. No one came up; no one called back to say they were delayed or anything. -When I gave the last two digits of our valet number to  the front desk to have our car brought around, she laughed and said. "that doesn't help me" then she mumbled under her breath "well, maybe it does." I just told her I'd call them myself. I gave them the same numbers and they brought the car around.-On our last morning, I called the extension for valet. No answer. So I called front desk (unfortunately same woman...double shift?) and said we'd there was no answer at the valet service and we'd like our car to head to airport. She said with a tone that they had just stepped away and I could call them back. Seems innocuous but the tone implied we were impatient even though she told us the night before to call the front desk if we couldn't get through to valet. -As we walked out of the hotel through the lobby, with bags in tow past the front desk, the same woman didn't say a thing. It was 5:30 am. No one around and silent in a relatively small lobby. She saw us. All hotel employees offer some sort of salutation as you enter/leave. Nothing from her! Not a peep! We had transferred to this hotel from a Red Rood + to "live it up" but it would've been better to stay put. They were clean, VERY friendly and accommodating. No attitude, no excuses. Just GREAT, PROMPT service. Stay there: 111 Nationwide Blvd. Columbus, Ohio 43215When we returned our rental car to Enterprise, it was quite the opposite as well. The attendant was cheerful and courteous. When I realized I hadn't gone to the gas station, without saying a word, he checked us out and when he tore off the receipt, he told us he only charged for 1/4 tank instead of half and if the service was good. I told him it was excellent. And then he asked us (before we could ask him) if we knew how to get to enter the airport. Then gave us directions.My two cents...RaeGinajust trust me this is 2 stars at mostI travel to Columbus weekly and stay at a variety of hotels downtown. This Sheraton is not bad and with a few basic improvements it could be solid.Good: comfy beds, big rooms, good A/C, Fat Tire on tapBad: Slow internet - not slow as in I can't stream HBO GO, but slow as in text web pages are slow to load. I did a speed test each night this week and the dowload speed is .25mb/second.Had a long drive and pulled into the Sheraton. We were greeted with a kind person at the front desk. We then went to the bar for a drink and John the bartender was so accommodating, very friendly, and really made our experience a positive one at the Sheraton in Columbus, Ohio. The rooms are very nice too!The hotel was average. It was sufficient, but not modern. The room service was extremely limited, but there's plenty of great eating places nearby. There's even a Starbucks inside the hotel. The wine list was very limited. Bad phone reception in my room; junior suite. My cellular phone calls constantly dropped calls. The bed was really comfy and the view in my room was spectacular. The furniture is dated and the colors were brown, white, brown and brown. New furniture definitely needed-- not upscale or modern. The hotel staff was exceptional. Every level of staff was friendly and helpful. If pressed, I would stay there again. The rates are very fair. I travel a lot so I have to give it two stars. But I am hopeful they will upgrade...eventually.The tenth floor doesn't have good signage for where your room is - signs are only located at the elevator (right above the buttons), but not the hallway. Room 1024's bathtub didn't drain. The shared door between rooms is VERY thin-can hear all of your neighbor's conversation (including morning alarms, tv, cell phone conversations, etc). I was not on the SPG floor (didn't have the SPG emblem), so maybe the rooms are better on the SPG floors.The reservations button on the phone directs you to the restaurant, not the hotel reservations desk. Valet parking will tell you they'll have your car ready in ten minutes, and they really do mean that. Valet parking was $23/day but the room rate was $99/night so can't complain too much. Valet parking was severely understaffed on Monday, 15Apr2013, at 9AM.In case you're unfamiliar with Sheratons, wifi and breakfast are not free. The bottled water was free, although there is no fridge to put the bottled water in (no microwave either). The only reason why I really stayed here was for the Starwood Preferred Guest (SPG) power up promotion (stay four times at a SPG property, get 2,000 bonus points).When you get your hotel bill under the door, the template by default states "If you had a SPG account number on file, you would've earned X points." I went to the front desk the next morning to clarify, and they assured my number was on file. They were correct, as the points showed in my account later in the week, but just know that this is an idiosyncrasy. I think the worst part (besides the non-draining bathtub) was that I talked to a lady named Heidi in person from reservations on Monday morning. I explained I have a room block at the Holiday Inn nearby in September and was wondering if the Sheraton would be willing to match. I gave her all the details - dates, number of rooms, purpose, etc. It's been nearly a week, and no one from the Sheraton has emailed. I guess they don't want the business!I just stayed here and had an excellent experience. The valet and desk staff were excellent - all smiles and very nice. My room was clean, modern in all respects, the bathroom was very nice, and the beds were amazing. Just about everywhere I stay, there always seems to be something that causes a headache of some sort - might be a small issue, might be a big issue - but my stay at this property was a wonderful experience with no issues or concerns at all. Thank you!it's ok.  I think the place is dusty.  I have to travel there for work a few times a month.  Gym is great.  New machines and water available.I work as a Women's competitive gymnastics coach in Ann Arbor. This year and last they held the USAG Region 5 Congress at the Hilton down the street. Usually we book a hotel room at the hilton since it is more convenient for the long days, where you just want to go up to your room...take a nap in-between sessions or change. This year we booked a little late so there weren't rooms available. So we booked at the Sheraton. Our boss forgot to book a room for Thursday night, luckily they had rooms available and the front desk was very accommodating. The valee parking is $23 per day with in and our privileges...which seems a little high. I understand you're a city but Chicago hotels sometimes don't charge a parking fee or it's less than $23...since I understand you have to rent the space. The hotel was very clean and had a good layout. The view was nice. The bathrooms were very spacious and clean. Only thing I disliked were the bed sizes...tiny. The free wifi is a plus, although you tend to get kicked on and off a lot. But I won't argue since you don't have to pay.Would definitely recommend to anyone if it is listed cheaper than the surrounding hotels.8/15 update.  I have screwed around on 4 calls with the hotel & SPG because they shorted me several thousand points.  Calls to the hotel... Oh we'll fix that right now.  Calls to SPG... Oh we'll fix that right now.  3 months later no cooperation.  WORST EXPERIENCE EVER!!!  The hotel staff are nice.  Unfortunately, the food is terrible, the restaurant screws up most orders or its cold or dry & generally ignores you.  I have only left one other restaurant l in my life.  I travel constantly, generally stay several weeks, eat at least a meal a day in a hotel's restaurants & get room service 2-3 times per week. I suffered through 4 meals and never ate there again.  You "reserve" a microwave for your room, don't get it, then promised for 2 days they'll get you one & then get told they don't have them.  I got a mini fridge that looked like it fell off a truck.  The rooms are terribly lit. I couldn't do work without having another lamp brought up.  The furniture is poorly thought out.  And, I came back to find they left the garbage 3 times.  You may be basically ok for an overnight.  But, there are 3 excellent hotels within 2 blocks.  I will never stay there by choice again.  I recommend you stay away from this hotel.Awesome location located a few miles from the Convention Center and Shore North.  Also, just behind the Columbus Commons so super convenient if there's an event or festival there.  I stayed here the week of the Food Truck Festival and loved it.  Beds are super comfortable and the room was clean.  Like most Sheraton properties, you won't find a microwave or a fridge.  Internet was $10 every 24 hours and parking is $23 per day.  I ended up parking on the street and feeding the meters as much as I could.  The city does ticket between 10pm and 8am and parking is free on Sundays.  Parking is a little inconvenient, but at least I didn't pay $46 bucks for parking for two days.If you also don't want to pay for internet, the Lobby floor has a few computers just outside Starbucks that provide free internet.Decent hotel in Columbus, probably the best you are going to find if you are SPG Platinum....Check in/check out - Very friendly, seem overstaffed which is great!!Rooms - can get pretty big, generally very clean, not much noiseGym - Gym is ok, not too much space but not too many users either. Weight equipment isn't the best but make up for it with cardio equipmentFree shuttle - Dave the free shuttle driver is great. Tip him and he will offer to come and pick you up as well as drop you offFood - Standard hotel food, nothing extravagant or awful. Just averageLocation - Not the best location but only a short cab ride from south high street where there are plenty of restaurants/nightlifeOther - Starbucks in the building is handyLounge - OK free food and sodasIt was okay. The room was larger than most hotels, semi updated, but not many amenities. There's no pool, small lobby, and subpar restaurant. The staff were very nice, and very friendly.Very good location many things to do within walking distance. very nice clean rooms and friendly staff.  One of the most comfortable beds I have ever slept in.Newly renovated rooms, great beds. A truly 4 star hotel right in the center of downtown Columbus.Great experience so far... I'm here for five nights (possibly longer) and everyone has been extremely friendly. I have a standard king size bedroom & it's large with a great view. The room service and valet are quick, prompt and polite. The walls are THIN though, there are a group of girls next door and I can hear them all night.
review_content_40: Decent room though no mini-fridge.  Lovely view of Columbus Commons.  Meters directly across the street from the front entrance are free on Sunday, which makes a Saturday night stay very convenient.If you need to find yourself or occupy a room without high incidentals, this is the place for you.Where to start... I'm not sure how long ago the hotel was under renovation, but there was about an inch of construction dust filth along the corners of the floor. That didn't just happen in one room, but two. The last room we were given actually had mascara on the sheets. And then there's the valet. not only did the attendant refuse to bring our car around, he managed to leave the valet station unattended long enough for us to retrieve our own keys - anyone cold have stolen any set of keys hanging there! When we came back the next day to discuss our experience the night before, the day attendant gave us the keys to someone else's car! The only shining star of this hotel was the staff, who did everything in their power to make the situation right. At the end of the night, we ended up at the Hyatt, where we usually go. (I guess you get what you pay for.)Friendly staff, helpful, tends to my needs when needed.Great location and very open ambiance. High ceiling, lots of choices to do work when you don't want to stay in your room. Either the bar, the restaurant, Starbucks on-site and their working area in the lobby. I love it when I stay here, feels like home away from home.Great lobby, superb location, nice staff. Room refurbishment not bad, but not hard to tell which hotel this used to be. The hotel star quality seems closer to a 3-1/2 than a 4 on many levels. Housekeeping had trouble seeing "do not disturb" sign on door. Must have been new to them. Especially the third time they knocked. Sheraton Sweet Sleeper bed as comfy as ever. :)Stayed at the Sheraton during the weekend of the Ohio State - Iowa football game. Great location for a hotel- about a 15 minute walk to the hip area of town, the short north. The rooms are ok and the hotel itself is a little tired.  The gym has fantastic views on the top floor and the staff is very helpful. We had a little bit of a problem with an adjoining room and some drunk fans getting in at 2 AM in the morning. It didn't affect me much but the next morning was the Columbus Marathon and if I was running that race I would be extremely upset by these loud, drunk people arriving in late and making all that noise in the middle of the night.  But that's a one-off situation and it didn't affect how I rated the hotel. The solid three stars is spot on.Nice rooms, great location in the middle of it all!Awful for business travelers as the Internet does not work. They've been "fixing" the Internet for months now but nothing has changed. Everyone from my project has switched hotels.Stayed here just one night on business.  Check in was a little slow and disorganized, but the staff was helpful.  Room service and restaurant options were terrible, but luckily there are plenty of restaurants nearby.  Bottom line is that this is a serviceable hotel for business travelers.  I would consider staying here if I take another trip to Columbus.perhaps this is a bootleg sheraton.as a frequent business traveller, i can say with vast hotel experience that this place is terrible!!!i am writing this review from a down stairs computer at 9:42pm waiting for my room to be cleaned. you see, house keeping closes ealy in the day and they missed my room. gettng them to clean it was like pulling teeth.here are things to consider: - room not very clean - additional charge for any use of internet for each device (ipad, computer, iphone, etc.)  - restaurant is horrific  - room service dismal and limitted - staff is scarce and housekeeping is very rude - television reception quite poor - do not rent movie! i rented a movie and it was broken, pixelated, unwatchable. hotel argued that they could not refund)  - laundry service excessively pricey - coffee shop closes at 2pm - ghastly snacks available in room with a shocking alarm sounding any time you attemp to enter. (explained to prevent shoplifting) - no breakfast  - no airport shuttle serviceall this for $250.00 a night!with nothing additional included.luckily there is a hyatt two block away.too bad they wont help carry your bags over there.They have really done amazing things with this hotel since the last time I stayed there!  The remodeled lobby, rooms and addition of a Starbucks is really convenient.  I stayed here for almost a week and never had any problems with anything.  The people really treated us well and accommodated all of our needs!  Thank you!Nice hotel. Great fitness center. No pool or hottub. And we were woken up by this horrendous jackhammer sound. Probably explains why we got such a good deal.Home away from Home!  Does not get any better than this.  Great location and only $8 cab ride to Short North.  Very worth it!Plus:  renovated room.  And it stops there.  Walls were paper thin so we heard every word of the people next door.  And we heard the people upstairs flush the toilet and take a shower.  Skip the valet parking for $23 per night and self park around the corner for a flat fee of $5 per night for a weekend night.Nice facility in a great location. Friendly staff, but a couple of areas of concern. 1) light switch came apart. Looks like it had happened before, but hasn't been properly repaired. Possible fire hazard.  2) Ordered Room Service that came promptly around 4 pm. Put finished plate in halfway by 4:45 pm. Still there at 9 am the next day. Expected better. 3) Daughter called the basket to request a cab. 30 minutes later, no cab. Apparently they forgot to call the cab company. Did the big things well, inconsistent with the little things.We hosted a New Year's Eve 2011/2012 wedding for our daughter & son-in-law, here at the Sheraton Columbus at Capitol Square! it was simply fantastic! The staff was friendly, the service and food was tremedous. Executive Chef Jonathan Olson is from the Ritz Carlton in Boston and he and Chef Jason Baehr prepared a spectacular meal for our 320 guests. The meals were delivered on time, the food was delicious and served hot! The service led by Vernon Hill & staff was tremendous. Our guests raved about the venue, the food, the rooms, the staff, the lighting, the food, bar & restaurant service....all great. Our biggest treat was working with Chris Katsares, Director of Catering, David Houle II, Banquet Manager and the entire Sheraton 'A' Team!Sheraton: You made this Father of the Bride very happy & proud...Welcome to Columbus, Sheraton...and Happy New Year!....Rocky F.Hotel has serious maintenance issues and housekeeping flaws - mold, peeling wallpaper, mouse-sized dust bunnies in vents, rotten food left in fridge from previous occupant. I had to change rooms twice just to deal with the major disgusting issues. Still no reply phone call from hotel's GM after 7 days, and multiple conversations with the manager on duty. I have canceled all business reservations previously booked there through end of year and have cautioned business colleagues to find other options. I would recommend selecting other hotels in the area.Decent prices to be had via Priceline (paid $108 for a Saturday night, taxes and fees included). Not sure this place lives up to being a 4 star hotel, as designated by Priceline. Check in was a breeze and they fulfilled our request for a King sized bed instead of the 2 doubles we were assigned. Had a sorta decent view on the 11th floor overlooking the Commons. Room was big and pretty nice. Bed was super comfy. Not sure what was up with the RED stains on the lamp shade. Would it kill them to spend $5 for a new one? Tons and tons of windows -  the entire wall in the room and bathroom were windows. That was kinda cool except it being 15-20 degrees outside that weekend and jippy insulation. While our room was able to stay warm, the bathroom was absolutely frigid. The heat never had a chance to make it back there. In the bathroom there was an old heater switch but obviously didn't work because it was in the ON position but continued to stay under 50 degrees  in the bathroom. I never showered because that's how cold it was. Coupled with chilly tile floors, you better make a quick pee trip. Decent counter space, good sized mirror but it wasn't cleaned from the previous visitor (face wash/toothpaste splatter residue). Also the iron and ironing board were not safe - the iron kept falling on the floor?? No problem getting a cab - just call Blue Cab. They're very reliable and prompt (as long as you can get through on the line). Parking is $23 which is kinda an insane price for Columbus. Valet took forever to bring out car the next morning but that might of had to do with everyone checking out at roughly the same time. I can't say I've stayed in many 4 star hotels, but this doesn't seem to live up to 4 star expectations. OH did I mention housekeeping opening our door at 9am well before the 11am checkout? Yeah. Thankfully we had the interior locked so the door only opened it an inch or so. Don't they check to verify who has checked out before entering to clean?If you need to just stay somewhere quick for the night or are a business traveler not looking to have much of a social life, then this property is for you. I guess you could have a decent time if you never leave the hotel, but my husband and I are all about getting local and there was absolutely nothing to do around the hotel because all of downtown pretty much shuts down at 5pm. Definitly not the fault of the hotel, but you would think they'd try to make a relationship with the downtown businesses and convention center to keep their guests happy. I never saw a single taxi and we walked about 4 blocks away for dinner. We wanted to find a liquor store within walking distance, but CVS was closed. The front desk person said nothing was within walking distance. The next morning when we left, we drove right past one that was in perfect walking distance and was open long hours. Ridiculous! Comfy beds, good lounge bar, and nice shower, just a let down as far as local culture and things to do nearby. I recommend looking for an advanced purchase price to get you a good deal. If you crash here after a concert at Nationwide arena, then that's a good set up.This could be the worst Sheraton I have ever stayed in, but it was not my choice.  My work put me there.   I don't know if it was the lack of a recent vacuum job, the dirty bathroom counter, or the empty beer cans and water bottles in and under the cabinets.   Perhaps the thermostat being unable to find a temperature to stick with that did me in, or maybe the lack of attention to the sign hung on the door to skip the housekeeping that should have gotten me a free coffee or 500 SPG points toward a free stay.  The 10th floor room felt like it was older than me, and had a strange smell I could not identify.  Being that downtown Columbus basically closes for the evening, I took a chance on room service for dinner.  That was a little better, but I felt the need to wash the desktop before I ate.  I cannot recall a stay at a Sheraton or SPG hotel that made me feel like I was ready to check out before the first night finished.  Can't recommend this place.  A half marathon was going on in Columbus the day after I arrived, and the place was apparently sold out.  At least the hotel is located within 20 minutes from the airport.My boyfriend and I were in town from San Francisco in January visiting his family. Our room was very clean and nice, however, the best part about our stay was Glenda at the front desk! She was very helpful and treated us very nicely. She was wonderful and it was a pleasure to have her as the representative and front woman of the hotel. Thank you Glenda for being so pleasant! We were so tired and stressed from our trip and you were such a breath of fresh air!
review_content_60: Overrated.., nice staff but rooms that don't work and the hotel doesn't care. No mini fridges. We rented one and were told they were "out"...power was out to phone and tv and now toilet doesn't work...third world...at best. Will ask for refund but am sure will be greeted with smile and "no way"...

review_content: Quick notes for the Hyatt Regency Columbus:1st stay was for an IT business competition back in vocay school. I fell in love with my current husband here and it was great. One thing the elevators were slow. The rest was nice. :)2nd stay was for Ohayocon and the elevator speed has improved, still slow, but way better. The rooms are nicer now as well has having pretty good wifi. They use Ruckus and Cisco. One thing though on the free tier remote desktops weren't working well. The rooms are very nice though and the beds were comfy. Great place to crash after the con :)  No real complaints about the rooms other than the lack of a fan/vent in the bathroom for BG noise and to let the smells out. The lobby was nice, and the staff were great. Too bad they had a leak though :( hope the place is ok!. The guy at the front desk was very nice and even covered our valet charge which was super cool and nice! They also ran the con stuff quite well and it was an awesome fluffy, fun time we had at Ohayocon and I miss it allready!Visited hotel to watch my Portland Timbers beat the Columbus Crew in the MLS CUP. Good: Great location with easy check in and great diamond breakfast. Bad: Older hotel and very stuffy. Ordered room service and never showed up. Hotel comped us lunch the next day to make up for it.Stayed December 2015Beautiful hotel. Rooms are clean and updated.Staff very friendly and helpful.Very close to all kinds of entertainment in the area. From restaurants to sporting events.Great place for a getaway.Stayed here with my mom for the Hot Chocolate 15K last weekend. Nice place to stay, but difficult to park in.We arrived about 2:30 pm and you pull into the turn around from the street, but it gets backed up easily since there's not a whole lot of space. There's a parking garage off chestnut street that does validated parking, $18 for self park, $20 something for valet parking. You can have your bags taken in and park or park and take them in yourself. Check in was fairly quick and painless and we headed up to our room. You could choose higher or lower floor, whichever your preference was. Restaurants on one the second floor or connected to the hotel. Easy access to the convention center. Close to the arena district (walking distance)Rooms were a good size, plenty of space. They have fridges in them for any left over food. Bathrooms were decent sizes as well. Clean and well kept.Check out was a breeze, you could do it on the internet or your phone if you didn't want to wait downstairsNo complaints.  I was here for work, where we held our small annual conference (~600 people).  It rained heavily for a few days while we were there, and the windowed ceiling near the convention center, by the small coffee shop would leak when it was very strong.  That wasn't a big issue, but many of our attendees complained about the dampness and mildewy smells in some of the meeting rooms and I noticed it in that area by the coffee shop.  I realize it's not something that can be easily or quickly corrected, but I hope management plans to redo that area soon.The room and amenities are nice. You just can't sleep in this hotel. The walls must be made of paper mache. You can hear EVERYTHING in the room next to you. Wonderful when the idiots next to you are making noise late at night. And then again in the morning.The Hyatt is a great place to host events. I have been to so many happy events here from weddings to organizational events. The only thing that throws me off each time is why the bathrooms are located on different levels and not the level you have the event at. I always have had events on the third floor because of the convenience of that space. For instance, today's event the Purple Teen Party was on the third floor but you would have not known that if the hotel did not put signs out directing you there. Actually I didn't get a sign I had a person directing me to that floor. Parking can be rather pricey but if you are staying here it's well worth it. I got a discounted rate today for my event to park at the East lot from the Hyatt for only $4, which is a killer rate if you ask me. Normally the price is around $10 or more. I'm not sure if the staff at the hotel made the treats we ate today at the hotel but they were phenomenal! We had mini key lime pies, lemon bars, cookies, bagels, cream cheese, coffee and juice. We had an incident here today where somebody accidentally pulled the fire alarm at the hotel so we weren't sure if we have to evacuate the hotel. Thankfully the Columbus Police were also there so they said it's okay that we just stay inside until the alarm turns off. Usually you would have to evacuate the building until there is an all clear to go back in. Since I live in Columbus I have no need to ever stay here but I would imagine it to be a very nice hotel room if you were booking a room. I would think you would also get a great view of the city if you slept here. Also you have 89 Fish and Grill across the street which I heard is awesome and can't wait to try someday! My only suggestion for the hotel in the future is to please utilize that first floor to instruct people who are lost where to go. As in maybe putting signs for events occurring there for the day, it would be very helpful so that I don't have to wait half an hour and be late to my event. Thanks and I hope everyone else enjoys their stay at this hotel as well.I stayed at the Hyatt Regency for several nights over Columbus Pride Weekend and really enjoyed it (despite the lobby's poor selection of late-night delivery menu options). I really liked staying here and my room was pretty swank. It was actually, literally, no-joke, bigger than my entire apartment back home, so that was nice. The showers got super hot, the sink had plenty of room to spread out my massive amounts of shiz, and there's even a vanity area outside the bathroom in case you do have someone else there who also needs to get ready. It was just me on this stay but I still used both areas, just because I could. The sleeping/living/work area was really nice too. There was a nice big desk, a chaise lounge, stylish lamps, a great big bed with super comfy pillows, a big dresser with a huge flat screen (They had HBO, but otherwise it was just super lame channels. Like 10 sports channels - no joke.), and the one wall was a huge panoramic window looking out to Columbus' skyline, which was super nice, and if you're not a fan of the skyline you could just close the blackout curtains and the room was no less comfy. The negs here (below) are few and far between, and really very minor in the long run. - The hallway smelled like smoking despite being on a supposedly non-smoking. My room, however, smelled fine, so you don't have to smell the stink for too long.-  The 4 elevators they have for the whole hotel are kind of a joke. On a busy weekend like the one I'd stayed here on, the elevator situation will leave you waiting for what seems like an eternity... and walking up and down from the 7th floor just wasn't in the cards for this lazy lass. - TV channels, as mentioned earlier, were kind of lame.- They had complimentary wifi on my visit for the special weekend, but otherwise I think they make you pay, which is total BS, IMO, when you're paying $200 a night for a hotel. Major props to Wil at the front desk who helped me check in and direct me to various exits and entrances since this hotel is connected to the convention center and not quite intuitive with several escape routs on various levels. He was mega friendly and helpful and really stood out as far as his dedication to customer service. He honestly made me feel like I was staying at the Ritz.This hotel has nice beds and a wonderful view of the city, but don't lose your receipt if you are on business the hotel will not give you another one. After talking to several people I found this to be disheartening that there was "Nothing they can do to email me another receipt".I also found there to be mold in the bathroom, carpets not vacuumed well and my TV blacked out and I had to keep shutting it off, neither did the IHOME/IPOD/Clockradio work. The room was too hot for my liking even when the "air-conditioned" room temp was set on 60 degrees, you can only put the fan on, No actual air.  Overall, if you can overlook these minor details. It is a convenient location to the arena district and the North Market all within walking distance. parking seems to be far away but with the skywalk, its just a few minute walk.Rooms are really nice and comfortable! I stayed here for a conference and it was nice that the hotel is attached to the conference center. The pool was the saddest I've ever seen, but I would guess that most people staying here don't really have time to visit the pool. As I said though, the rooms were really comfortable, especially the beds! I didn't have any issues checking in and out, and would certainly love to come back here be it for a conference or otherwise.Check in was super efficient and my room was an extra-large city view king, which I loved. Great home base for my stay in CMH which was for a wedding.For some reason, they didn't deliver a New York Times, as promised, but the WSJ, which I like quite a lot less. No big deal on a short stay, of course. The rooms were well-appointed, although they forgot to stock soap, shampoo, and a bathmat, which I discovered the first night when I stepped into the shower. That was fixed posthaste, and the evening turndown service was excellent, with chocolates and bottles of water. The in-room coffee was delicious Starbucks dark roast and I enjoyed two cups every morning. For diamonds, they give up upgraded wifi, which was lovely. All Hyatts should do this as I definitely noticed the difference in speed. No Regency club, but great breakfasts at the restaurant.The pool area needs a lot of help; I would definitely NOT get in the water as it is disgusting. And the workout area is quite small, but well stocked. It'd be good for the hotel to spend a little money on upgrades there, frankly.Very well located in the heart of the downtown area.All in all, a good city-center Hyatt Regency, but there are better ones, too. That said, I'd stay there again when in CMH.I've stayed here twice now (For Origins 2014 and 2015) and both times have been a fan. The staff is incredibly helpful, and the hotel is clean and shiny. The rooms are very good - however I will say that the double-room beds are not *nearly* as comfortable as the King size beds. They are just "okay" and not amazing.Great central location. Within half mile of most of Columbus' downtown attractions including Nationwide Arena, North Market and Short North district. I had no safety concerns walking around during the evening. I booked through Hotwire for a rate of about $90 per night. I was mostly satisfied with my stay.The room was well maintained and furnishings were up to date. The lady at the desk was nice enough to ask us if we had a floor preference. She put us on the 17th floor which had a nice view of the downtown skyline.Overall, not a bad option if you want to explore downtown Columbus and the Short North district. Despite having a dated appearance on the outside and in the lobby, the rooms are actually pretty nice. I had no issues with noise. If anything it was almost too quiet!Parking is a bit of a nuisance. If you choose to valet your car, it's $25 for unlimited in and out access. If you want to park yourself, there are multiple lots available within 5-10 minutes walk that cost up to $20 per day. Valet may be the easier choice. Another downer is that you have to pay for internet access.Great customer service,  beautiful and clean room.  Front desk person made an honest mistake and wrote the wrong room number on my access card.  I had to go back down to the lobby to get it fixed.  I wasn't upset,  told her it was no problem.  Found 6 chocolate 'buckeyes' (dessert) and a hand written apology note in my room an hour later.  Wow.  So nice!Great location just a half block from all the Arena venues.  Spacious lobby.  Quick check in.Rooms are furnished well.  I like the chaise lounge instead of the typical chair or sofa.  Big windows in the room let please type of light in.  Big King bed that was  very comfortable. Only 'complaint' was my rooms heating & cooling. Waaay too loud and even the slightest variation on temp was overkill. Either too hot of too cold.  Probably just the room I was in, so not a big deal.Nice place and will be back.This is a review only for the bar and restaurant. At the Hyatt I want a bar area that doesn't remind me of a high school cafeteria. The dining area also didn't seem very inviting.My colleagues and I explored the in-hotel beer drinking and dining options, decided we could do better, and on both days we were there headed to Wolf's Ridge Brewing (about a 5 minute walk away and a very nice place to hang out).I really enjoyed my three night stay here.  Room 833 has to be one of the coolest rooms I have ever stayed in.  Loved the layout and all the windows.  Check in was easy, staff was friendly.  Was brought up free razor and q-tips very quickly when requested.The room service was hit or miss.  First night I ordered a steak very late - almost midnight and it was terrible.  The worst steak or potatoes I have ever had.  Second night I just ordered water and beer and got food from the convention center food court.  Third night I tried room service again - a burger with blue cheese and avocado and it was delicious.  This was more at 6 pm so perhaps the time made a difference?Only bad parts about hotel was the elevators were sosososososo slow!  I had to wait 10 minutes each time I wanted to go up or down - which was often with the conference I was attending.  Also, $10 per day for internet.  Not sure I was actually ever charged though even though I had to approve the charge on my laptop when I signed in...This hotel is clean, rooms are big and the starbucks coffee in your room in the morning is a huge plus. However, they don't have a 24-hr accessible front desk extension or mini mart for basics - water, snacks, etc. this is a huge fail in my book. The general store in the lobby isn't open late to grab things after you return from dinner. When I checked into my room a garbage can hadn't been emptied and there were some other signs that the room wasn't cleaned up and down, but I can live with that. I was more frustrated when I drank my in room tea night one and it wasn't replaced, even though I left the wrappers out to show it was used. The real kicker for me was that the bed uncomfy. This usually isn't an issue at hotels with this kind of "nicer" business feel. I just can't get comfortable and it's too bad.I have stayed here every time I have visited Columbus. It's location is ideal. Connected to the Convention Center and close to the Arena District and the Short North. I have always found the staff incredibly professional and accommodating. This weekend in particular there was a rock concert, breast cancer walk, 3 conventions and 8 weddings all going on at once and the level of service we received was unchanged. The room was clean and set up very nicely. And we really enjoyed our stay.Tremendously disappointed with this hotel.  Room was not worth the price. Wall paper was peeling. The breakfast bar was an equal let down. Definitely not worth the price.
review_content_20: Great look and the room is nice. Very close to everything. Nice customer service. Doormen weren't very friendly or professional looking. Would stay again.We stayed here for a conference at the Greater Columbus Convention Center. The location was extremely convenient, especially to the convention center. It is a 2 minutes walk, all indoors! The room was very clean, the workout facilities was nice (and included free-weights), and the hotel bar was very cool.The staff and service was great!The only reason I am not giving it 5 stars is because it doesn't come with free Wifi. It seems like a hotel in this price range should include complementary internet service.The overall hotel was modern and elegant. Great location, easy access to most of the Columbus hot spots. The rooms were big, with large picture windows providing wonderful views of the area.We had brunch with the family at the in-hotel restaurant, Marketplace Cafe. The buffet had plenty of choices - standard cereals, fruits, but also had a made-to-order omelet bar. I would go with the buffet every time, the service is too slow otherwise.I do have to discount the review for paid Wifi - for the overall cost of the room you would think such small incidentals would be included.My boss sent me here during the week of December 15-19 for business and found the place to be very comfortable. I've looked at pictures at the room on their website and my room didn't look anything like those. My room was dark, meaning dark grey wallpaper on the walls, with a dark deco in the entire room. I didn't have a great view (room #617) but I really didn't care about the view. I'm guessing this was a room that hasn't been upgraded but it's still the "Hyatt Regency."The very first day, I had a salad on the 2nd level restaurant which was really good and drinks at the bar later on that evening. Some of the things I didn't like about this stay is they charge you for parking your vehicle at the hotel. $16 a day at the Chestnut parking garage or you can valet park for $25 a day. Plus they charge you for using the internet, which I refused to do. There wasn't much to do in the area after hours and the place was practically a ghost town. I was told it was because of the time I was visiting Columbus. Every time I got on the elevator, I was alone,....a true ghost town during that week.Other than that, it's a nice place to stay.My dad is a gamer (war games, role playing games, etc.) It's not my cup of tea, but the bright side is that when he travels for conventions I travel along and get my own mini vacation. Every year we stay at the Hyatt for the Origins convention. For the longest time the Hyatt has been the quintessential hotel for conventions, being conveniently connected the Columbus Convention Center. Our room was on the 17th floor this year, and it didn't face the Arena District. Not a big deal for us, considering my father spends the majority of his time at the convention and I at Easton and North High. However, if you're hankering for a view to wake up to, request an Arena District room. I believe if you're into that sort of thing it's worth the extra $10-15. The room was comfy as always; this year, the shower had an issue draining and it made funny noises. It didn't bother me enough to tell someone, and that's my fault. It's a plumbing issue I'm sure they'll get right on. The amenities seem fantastic; there's a pool, fitness center, bar and sun deck. I say seem because it doesn't live up to the hype of a Hyatt Regency. The pool had absolutely nowhere to put your belongings, and it seemed poorly kept. (I'm not one to go to Columbus to swim anyway, but I travel a lot and it wasn't very comforting.) The fitness center sufficed for regular business travelers, but if you have the time I recommend running around downtown Columbus. It's a lot safer than other downtown areas and the weather while I was there was PERFECT for running. Hyattathome.com offers reasonably priced workout wear if for some reason you forgot your compression shorts or shirts. The sun deck was blah. It's on the bottom floor, which defeats the purpose of a sun deck, and was a drag. It was decently well kept, but the sun didn't hit it very well and people walking in and out of the hotel can see you attempting to enjoy the sun. It's an awkwardly placed "sun deck".The food and beverage is nothing to write home about. The coffee shop advertises fresh baked goods but let's be honest...no. The bar was overran by gamers (which scares me), but if I were to enjoy the bar, 3.75 Pabst Blue Ribbon isn't how I would do it. With the plethora of bars and restaurants down the street, there's no reason you should prefer to stay within the hotels for drinks or food.Which brings me to why this hotel is awesome: location. It's one block from Nationwide Arena (for when I come for Blue Jackets games), two blocks from the North Market (where I eat lunch EVERYDAY YAAAS!) and considering it's right in the middle of the hubbub on N High, you can go either direction and find many activities. Also, with it being connected to the convention center, you can explore for daaaaayyyysss. I like exploring, sue me. The food court is connected to the Hyatt and it's open late. My nights consisted of getting velvet ice cream and sitting in lobby watching World Cup soccer on the projection they had on for the first and second floors. Yes.The convenience of getting to your room has never been a selling point here. It's gotten so bad that they've opened up the freight elevators at night. Also, the escalator connecting the first and second floor is down for 6+ months. Not a big deal to me because I enjoy walking and the construction created the most adorable area in the lobby for me to do work, but for convenience, it's horrific. The convenience of checking and out is where I am totally different from my other Yelpers. Hyatt has made it very easy to check in and out; you can do it with the kiosks in lobby, on your TV, or through your email! If you take the time to look, you can check in and out in 5 minutes flat.Parking is okay. It's 16 a night if you want in/out privileges, 12 if you just don't care. I can't walk to Polaris, Easton or the nearest Canes, so 16 a night it is. The walk to the hotel from the garage is a long one, but it's only excruciatingly long if you're lazy. If I'd have any advice for the Hyatt, it'd be to be careful. Obviously you're going to have competition. You're smack in the middle of downtown. We almost stayed at the Crowne Plaza until I convinced otherwise, but upon exploration I found the Crowne to have activities and amenities I'd much prefer (bonfire at night in their patio? YES!). I've also stayed at the Hampton for business and I was ridiculously happy there. I typically stay at Hilton owned hotels for business but staying at the Hyatt is a tradition for my dad and me. I love the Hyatt, don't get me wrong. It's comfortable and the staff is friendly (and attractive. Can I say that? Too late I did. They have good looking bell hops and valet people.) However, with the expectations constantly rising, I want to be wowed. I'll be up again for leisure in October, and I don't know if I'll stay here or at another hotel across the street. I can't whole heartedledly recommend the Hyatt until they change their formula.Good location near downtown, Arena District and Short North. Speedy check in and check out electronically. Valet parking was solid. Room was nice but the bathroom in our room was a little cramped. But it was a good stay.This review is for the conference rooms. I've been to a few conferences and receptions here at the Hyatt and I think the facilities are good. White table cloth rooms, good service, etc. My really only complaint is that the catering food is not that great.We stayed here after visiting Columbus winter beerfest. This turned out to be a great decision. When we checked in the desk clerk gave us a "great room on a high floor". And he did. We were on the 15th floor and faced west so we had this amazing view of the Arena district and downtown. Overall, the room was very comfortable. The bathroom is well-appointed and nicely decorated. The bed was pretty comfy, although, ours had a dip in the middle. I did not like the pillows, I probably would have slept better without any pillow. We also ate dinner at the Cafe on the 2nd floor. It was pretty good, a bit pricey but it was good. After beerfest, we had a post-game pint at the Big Bar on 2. The bartenders were fabulous; super friendly and they knew their stuff... we spent much of the night talking beer and drunk watching. It was a hoot. We'll definitely stay here again for the next beerfest.I stayed at a Hyatt for the first time and was pleasantly surprised at how great both the location and the hotel itself was. The room and view from the room was quite nice. we were in room 746 overlooking the arena district. The one thing I didn't like about the room were the pillows, they weren't quite fluffy and it seemed like every pillow had a different feel then the other, which actually turned out to be a good thing because I was able to find one pillow I liked. The beds were comfortable and we were very rested afterwards. I would definitely try to book a Hyatt on my other trips, and this location in particular is a treat!Stayed here in February for a conference. Love that it is connected to the convention center. The room was good size and clean, a little on the dark side. The omelette in the hotel restaurant were fabulous. The staff was kind and accommodating. I would strongly recommend the online check in/out as the line to do so was a long one. The only down side were the elevators. They were very slow and often too full by the time they reached you and you had to wait for another one. I walked the stairs a few times but that was exhausting when you are farther than the 6th floor!Nice hotel. Quick check-in...did online check-in so getting my key was fast since I already knew my room number. Lobby was clean. Elevators were relatively quick each time I used them. Room was updated and clean. Bathroom was small compared to rest of room, but not terrible. Low ceilings.Signage to get from parking garage (Chestnut Garage) wasn't clear at first but I figured it out. Sky way must not have air conditioning or ventilation is poor cause it was hot, muggy, and air smelled "stale". Cost for daily parking is a bit expensive, but not awful.In not sure what the regular room rate is as I'm here for work with a conference rate. But my rate is very reasonable. Can walk to many different restaurants. Very convenient that the hotel is contacted to conference center.This was our second vacation here and it's now safe to say I will never stay at another hotel in Columbus!!! The rooms are clean with beautiful views, all of the employees are extremely friendly,there is sit down restaurant, Starbucks, Einstein's, and a food court. They also have a gift shop that has anything you might need and even an Ohio state buckeyes team shop!!! I would really like to focus on the bar on level 2 some of the best times we've had on both our visits have been at this bar! The bartenders are all friendly, funny, and fast! Do yourself a favor and stay at this hotel and do not skip the bar!!!I was here for a conference and expo for work. I had a Panoramic King Room on the 19th floor and the view was wonderful. All of the staff was very helpful and nice. The hotel was very clean. Conveniently located within walking distance to the Arena District and Short North. I will definitely stay here again.Overall, the best qualities of the hotel are the staff (Wil at the front desk is fantastic.) and the ease of getting to and from the conference center... those two things brought it up from a 2 star review. My room was sad... contemporary and gorgeous in style but the cleanliness was shoddy at best. Dusty vents, leaking window, peeling and discolored wallpaper, and chewed gum on the table edge (got to find that while fumbling around for the lightswitch). But the view? Amazing. Also, parking not being included, and charging for wifi let's me know how much they value their customers... I stayed two nights and paid nearly $50 in parking (and never even left.) That said... would I stay there again? Probably, because it's so darn convenient... and truly that and the staff are the only reason they are successful. I wanted to love it, and it appeals to my laziness during the hecticness of conferences, but I ended up leaving a day early. Price just couldn't justify the mediocre experience.Great hotel - friendly staff. Very conveniently located near the convention center. We were able to upgrade to a Jr. Suite, which I highly recommend. The added space (which is generous) really makes a difference, especially since we were there 10 days!Love the Hyatt Regency Hotels - would definitely stay there again.I love the city of Columbus and we generally gave to stay at the Hyatt when we are in town. The hotel staff is above average. At check in we were treated very well. They offer front door Valet parking for a daily fee. The rate isn't too bad.The hotel could use a makeover. It's a little outdated. They keep it fairly clean but it's in need of renovations. The rooms are fairly decent in size but again they could be updated.Overall, I liked this location for a conference I attended. The food service was good, especially the breakfast. Some of the older wait servers were....interesting. At times not paying attention to what they were doing or the tables needs. The conference rooms were what you would expect. Staff was helpful in moving tables or assisting with technology. The internet/WiFi was ok, just not the most reliable. Rooms and furniture appeared to be new or recently purchased so they invested in keeping the conference services up to date. My issues was parking...maybe they offer this and my conference just did not buy in, but it would have been AWESOME if they would have a deal for conference participants to have discount parking. $16-$18 a day was rough when you are at a conference for 4 days. Find parking for $10 a day means I would have had to walk a far distance after the conference (at night, maybe alone) to get to my car.New Years was the con of all cons. Thanks for the premium tickets that you didn't serve except at two bars.This is a pretty standard hotel, not bad rooms but the beds are a little too firm and just enough light and noise enter the room to ensure a not completely restful sleep. There is a pool and fitness area, the fitness area seems well appointed but the pool... the brick wall, exposed pipes which skirt the ceiling and stark fluorescent lighting give the pool something of a municipal quality- as if you are using the world's nicest prison pool. One area of excellence is the staff of the hotel; they are very friendly, accommodating and quick with a kind word or smile. Grace at reception was a particularly excellent brand ambassador.This review is for my check in experience. I reserved a room with a king sized bed 3 months ago for a conference in November. When I got to check in, the associate said that they do not have a king but a double twin room.
