Grudgingly I accept and half way through the check in process another more veteran looking associate comes over and says "oh you can't give her that room, I need it for the customer I was working on". Biting my urge to snare at the veteran associate for her rude interruption, I calmly ask the associate what rooms are left. LONG STORY SHORT I ended up in a room with a pull out couch bed. They kept on reiterating that it has a 5 in mattress foam pad, which by the way makes no difference. I slept in a room with no comforters and couch cushions piled on one end of the bed. To top it off, they wont even cover breakfast for my entire stay, I got one day comped out of the 4 night stay and they made a big deal out of this. Still waiting on seeing if they have another room available.Talk about horrible customer service and crappy hotel stay!
review_content_40: We stayed here for a conference and overall I really enjoyed our stay. - Dog friendly - our corgi kinda goes with us everywhere, so a truly dog friendly hotel is always important to me. Their pet fee is paid once for your entire stay and it's very reasonable, which is nice (rather than a daily rate). Everyone from the front desk to the bellhops were so friendly to my dog. - Clean, Spacious rooms - we were on the top floor, 20, but the elevator rides were quick. The hallways aren't too long so no matter what you shouldn't need to walk a long way to your room. Rooms are quiet, and there are alot of amenities like a small fridge (no freezer), coffee & tea maker, ipod dock/clock. - Prompt room service - we ordered breakfast; it arrived when they said it would and the quality of the food was good. - Dog walking areas - there's some grassy areas directly in front of the hotel and then across the street going towards the college campus. Everything is very clean - so be a good dog owner and clean up after your doggie too :). - Convenient walking distance to the convention center (connected within the hotel) and to restaurants nearby. It's college town though FYI, but there's a good mix of adults too. Would definitely stay here again.This hotel is located/connected to the Columbus Convention center.  Fleet Fleet Columbus held a MIT day before the marathon warm up run here.  We all met in the north lobby area to gather before we ran 3 miles that day.  The hotel has a small shop inside where you can pick up a bite to eat.great staff with wonderful service., clean rooms, i had a beautiful view with huge windows.i was suprised how small the pool was, no hot tub either . most come here for the other ammenities because its a conference center but the pool and fitness area are lacking when you consider a Hyatt.no continental breakfast ifvthats important to youseriously $10.00 a night for internet, what the heck is that about????The hotel was nice and the view was pretty. Definitely opt for the valet since it's a decent trek from the parking garage to the hotel (especially with suitcases). Overall, the experience was great and I will definitely be returning to the hotel if I ever come back to Columbus.Stayed there last night. The staff was very friendly and helpful and the room was nice. It was located in a nice area of downtown and though I didn't get a chance to really explore, it seemed like a pretty cool area to walk around.Room was clean. Bed is a little too firm for my taste. Bathroom clean. What really pisses me off is they charge for the Internet. $10 per day!  Who charges for Internet anymore?  You pay an ass load for a room, then the want to slam extras down your neck.I also tried eating breakfast at the resturant the next morning. The sign said wait to be seated. I waited for 10 minutes before giving up and going without. It's looking to me like customer service is not #1 here.Hyatt always comes through for me. This is a nice one like the others. The people are super nice and friendly. I went to my room and it smelled like a smoker was in there and they switched my room no problem. The wi if is awful slow and the tv is not High Def so lame the tv can do it but they send an analog signal to it super doh!!!  Other than wi fi and tv it's great. Step up Hyatt Columbus it's 2014 not 1999 give me fast wi if and HD.This Hyatt is pretty great.Work placed me in this hotel for a few days as I attended a conference on behalf of a client. Although I arrived late at night, the front desk staff was prompt and helpful at check in, and I was in my room in under 5 minutes. Truth be told, I am a germophobe and as soon as I check into a hotel my eyes dart around the room looking for any sign(s) of grubbiness. Fortunately, my room was clean, so I was able to relax.Throughout the rest of my stay, the staff remained friendly and my room was cleaned very well each day. The front desk has complimentary toiletries available - which worked out well for me as I forgot to bring deodorant. The front desk also has a free flight check in kiosk where you can check into your flight and print your boarding passes - and if the printer is acting up, the staff will print your boarding passes from one of the printers behind the desk. What's also great is that the hotel is connected to the convention center, so you don't need to step out into the elements if you're participating in any convention center activities.The only thing that bothered me about this hotel is that the walls seemed pretty thin. I could hear random conversations from other rooms at several points during my stay, but it wasn't that big of a deal as the noise was pretty muted.I'd definitely stay here again.Friendly service impeccable service awesome shower clean rooms I didn't like the faucets in the bathroom,  the spray get you all wet when you wash your hands. Green team for your recycling. Valet took exceptionally long and it's hard to put your makeup on any of the mirrors,  1 is too dark and the other you have to lean over the counter, too far for someone who is short.I would stay here again!Rating this hotel was difficult. I wanted to give it five stars, but there were just a few annoyances and one consistently subpar item I could not ignore.First, the room. By all means, request a corner king room!!! And make sure it's a *34, that's room 934, for example. There is a similar room on the other side of the hotel, but I am not sure of the room number. I saw into the adjacent corner king and I was reminded of a review I read on Yelp by someone that said their corner king was WAY too small. My guess is he was in a *33 room. Those rooms have four windows total. Mine, a *34, had six (this includes the bathroom). The room was huge, comfortable and top notch in every way... almost.Okay, now for the not so good stuff. I'll start with the towels. They didn't smell good. I mean, I know hotel towels are usually rough and I don't expect them to smell like flowers, but these towels (all of them) smelled slightly rank, like maybe they were washed without detergent. I'm certain that's not the case, but the bottom line was, "Ewwwwww". Towels should not smell nasty at a Hyatt.My second complaint is a result of the $9.95 a day charge for access to the internet. I have stayed in downtown San Francisco and received complimentary access to the internet. Here at the Hyatt, not only was it $9.95 per day, it appeared to be $9.95 per device. I can't verify because I stopped the connection process on my iPhone (after already connecting on my iPad) because it appeared the $9.95 charge would also come through for the second device. Driving in and leaving using valet parking was not exactly a challenge, but it did require a bit of patience. I imagine this is pretty status quo for downtown hotels. though I do recall staying in downtown Chicago where self parking was quite simple and convenient. I only interacted with the front desk and room service personnel. They were all very hospitable; I have no complaints.I'd love to come back and stay in a *34 room, but I don't want stinky towels, so I will probably find another place to stay.Big fan.Super nice place for the price ($60 Priceline Express Deal - it's almost always listed as the 4 Star Express Deal, or you can snag it that much in the name your own price most nights (or they may give you the Hilton across the street instead). Why pay full price?Very modern room, great view of downtown CMH as well. Some noise from the guests down the hall, but it is only hallway noise... Things are quiet from room to room.The three downfalls to this place are:1) Having to pay for internet.2) Parking. I get that it is downtown and limited parking, and that valet is nice (my opinion a hassle)... But I really am not a fan of the $18-$25 parking fee... But hey, it comes with the territory, and I get that. It's a 4 star hotel and they should offer this.3) The boarding pass computer/printer is terribly slow (at least on the Delta website). Seriously. Like took me 10-15 minutes to get my boarding pass slow.I would definitely stay here again.+Rooms were nice and clean. Pretty good view. Connected to Convention Center- Parking was a debacle, valet was a joke. Also, 4 elevators for 20 floors and 600 rooms? be ready to wait. Connected to Convention CenterThe location of the Hotel is prime. With in walking distance of the nationwide arena, among other hot spots. For the price I wasn't overly impressed however the view was nice, staff was friendly, and the room was too my liking for the most part. Biggest issue I had was that wifi cost $20 to use!This is based on their conference areas and their foodI came here for a conference over the weekend.  They work out good deals for parking which make it nice to have a conference here.  They have a lot of rooms to use which is nice and most of them can handle good amount of people.The food is Ehhh! at least their lunch food was so-so.  The Chicken was dry and lacked flavor.  I enjoyed the dessert and their breakfast.  They had oatmeal and yogurt options at Breakfast with plenty of fruit.  The coffee is decent and taste like a medium roast and brew.  They do have plenty of servers around but then they seem to disappear when you need them or take two waters off your table for another table even though more people are coming.They also don't have a bathroom close to the upstairs area.  I would like to see bathrooms in more convenient places.  Also this place is busy so your conference can get overrun by a lot of teenagers from other conferences.  It is in a nice location downtown.  Internet should be free because it cost over $10 a day.  Come on and let have some free wi-fi.I have stayed at this Hyatt several times.The location is good as it is located close to the arena district and the short north which I loveand connected to the convention center as well.I have stayed at this Hyatt several times for work and it is great. I will say if you don't like large hotels this isn't the place for you! It is attached to the convention center so the place is always packed and busy. It can get a little annoying  waiting awhile for an elevator but the corner rooms have a fantastic view and are incredibly spacious and everyone is so friendly. The ricotta pancakes for breakfast (room service) are pretty fantastic and if you are traveling by yourself eating at the bar is a great option. The bartenders are super friendly and the food is actually pretty good. They have a decent wine selection and I highly recommend the beer cheese soup.The valet system is not dialed in. Get judgmental looks when you don't call ahead for your car, but when you try to they don't answer if they are mildly busy.A nice Hyatt.  Hyatt's have the best soap, shampoo and conditioner, hands down.  I had a corner room on the 15th floor, and it was a bit like living in a fish bowl (wall to wall windows, even in the bathroom) but the room was clean and well laid-out.  I had cool views, and while the room struck me as odd at first, I actually quickly came to really like it.  Bed was comfy.  Staff were friendly and efficient at check-in and check-out.  The bar inside is crap if you like beer that isn't in the Coors to Budweiser range, so I never utilized it.  I would stay here again, and would stay at a Hyatt over a Hilton any day.This hotel is nice and clean they just need to work on their customer service skills and their vallet department is terrible, according to the hotel they sub this service out and claim no responsibility however they collect payment for this third party and refuse to explain this to guests unless there is a problem at which time they put there hands in the air and claim zero responsibility. Shame on you Hyatt regency. There are better hotels in downtown Columbus and I would recommend them over the Hyatt.I booked a night at this hotel for the annual Origins Gaming Convention this year. They gave us the convention rate which was under $200 for a king-sized bed room.Even before I stepped foot into the hotel, I was impressed by their communication. I had requested an early check-in and they had the room ready for me, letting me know via text message and email.Their staff was terribly friendly and efficient and I was up in my room on the 17th floor in no time. The view was good and the room was clean. A couple of small complaints though : their wi-fi was terribly slow and the room was a little small. In spite of that, I did have a very good experience staying at this hotel.
review_content_60: I thought I got an excellent value for a conference at a package rate of $132 a night.  The hotel is attached to the convention center.The good: the staff are friendly and helpful, the wireless was free for me by joining the Hyatt "club" loyalty program which is free (you don't have to get a credit card or anything).  There's a fitness center, bar, restaurant, and there are a lot of rooms with nice city views.On the bad side:The pool is terrible, unpleasant atmosphere and unless you have small children, it's so small and shallow I think it may be dangerous for most adults to swim in it. Also the rooms have a kind of limited selection of television stations.long over due remodel :)I stay here every year for a weekend conference.  They do an awesome job of turning over the hotel in a timely manner and the service desk is always friendly.The rooms have a great view of the arena district, flat screen TVs, and the most comfortable bed and pillow I have ever had in a hotel.They do have 40 minutes of free wi-fi in the lobby area, but charge for it in your room.There are a lot of restaurants in the surrounding area, a food court in the convention center, a coffee shop, and a bar. Things to improve on:elevator speedfree wi-fi in the roomsOk. Would expect more for the price. Much prefer Drury Inn across the street which is cheaper, offers identical rooms, free internet and free hot breakfast. They just happened to be booked this time around so I'm at the Hyatt. They are only riding on their name.Stayed here twice, first for a wedding and then for a business convention.  Overall I was pleased.  The rooms are comfortable and it's convenient to nearby attractions (the wedding was at the art museum which is a short cab ride away.)  The second time I stayed, the desk area wasn't entirely cleaned which was gross (hair and a bobby pin on the chair.)  I would consider staying here again depnding on where in the city I need to be.Not impressed for a Hyatt Regency. What has happened to this chain? The hotel seems to have gone through a recent renovation, but my room was dusty and the window covering was not sufficient. Seems like they stopped just short of finishing. It was a bit noisy as well, I could hear all the doors closing on my floor. Staff was friendly, but I think that they need a few more months of experience before this works out.I stayed here for two nights while in Columbus for work.Pros:-clean room-free wifi with Hyatt Gold-convenient valet for $23/night or parking garage across street for $12/night-noon checkoutCons:-new gym running equipment-gym towels not clean-small poolThe elevators are too few for the amount of floors. Otherwise, nice rooms and good location.I stayed here with a couple of friends for an event that was being held close by. Valet was $24/night, unlimited in and out privileges or you could park in the garage and pay each time to get in and out. We opted for valet because we had a lot of stuff to carry in. Check in was a breeze and we went on to wait for the slowest elevators ever. They were definitely busy so I'm not sure if that was the cause or not. Our rooms were nice as they have recently remodeled the hotel. We had two double beds and I love when the rooms are updated enough to have an Ipod dock. I wish more hotels would get with that program! So, we are getting ready and listening to music and a knock on our door at 4pm with our neighbor asking us to turn our music down because he is trying to sleep. Ok, it is 4pm, and our music isn't that loud, but I did the courteous thing and turned it down. At 2:30/3am, we have to call security because of the domestic going on in the same room the guy came from earlier. Awesome. The walls must be pretty thin, folks, that is all I can say. We checked out the little breakfast cafe and the bagels and fruit were fresh and they brewed starbucks coffee as well.My first room was moldy. I guess I am more sensitive than others, but if the shower curtain has been left to rot for a month, it's not a good sign anyway. I went down and spoke to Nicky, who was amongst the very helpful staff there. She moved me to another room that was clean and in good shape. She was very apologetic and was eager to keep me a satisfied customer, which I now am.Nice rooms but pricey and distant from the night action,Last year when I stayed here I probably would have given this place a 2 for some issues with cleanliness and bar service. But this year I was better pleased. My room was clean and comfortable. Valet guys were very polite and helpful with things like the location of the nearest Starbucks. The restaurant had some issues with breakfast, but given the size of the convention I was attending, this isn't surprising. They've installed a computer at the end of the front desk where you can print out boarding passes for free. This is a HUGE improvement over paying $10 for computer access for three minutes to do the same.The good stuff- you get a nice, clean, safe, almost upscale hotel, right on High Street downtown for between 100 and 170 a night, depending on when you go and if you're there with a group. The staff tries to be friendly, most of the time. And there is a wonderful food court, convenience store, pool, refrigerators, microwaves, and everything else you'd want extra thrown into a hotel.Now here's the less fortunate part- the basics. Internet and parking. Internet is 10 dollars per day, and if you have 2 people who both brought laptops, forget it. That's 10 dollars per connected computer.Parking is sometimes comped if you're there with a group or convention that negotiated for it. If you're not so lucky, or happen to not be the only person who arrived by car staying in your room, be prepared to spend a rather ugly amount of money on parking. Or simply park on the street in nearby Italian Village and hoof it- though it's hardly what I'd call convenient.These are only two complaints- so why only 2 stars? Because this is downtown COLUMBUS. It's a small downtown, accessible from the outerbelt in 10 minutes or less on a good day. Within said outerbelt, are dozens of hotels that cost $40 per night, offer free wifi in their rooms, free and plentiful parking, and a free continental breakfast.Which leaves me asking: Knowing that, why do people stay here?Long story short, the Hyatt could still charge what they do and earn themselves 5 stars. They're much cleaner and more finely appointed than most hotels, and are perfect if you simply must be walking distance from the convention center or arena district. But even though they could offer those little things for free, they simply won't. They're just not willing to put in the extra effort where most other hotels are.A score on hotwire for $77 to stay in September 2011. 3.5* Downtown Columbus - Arena District - German Village area hotel, Amenities: Fitness Center, Pool, Restaurant, Business Center, High-Speed Internet Access, Golf Nearby.Meh. Not a fan of charging for internet access, parking, and no breakfast. Maybe I ask too much from a downtown hotel?Great experience at the Hyatt! Walking distance to the arena district which has tons of upscale restaurants and night life. Staff has been very accommodating and the room is modern and clean.Love the room sizes, spacious and luxurious. They even offer free HBO. Good food offering in the hotel and is very close to a ton of restuarants.I was here for 3 days.  They host conventions so its better to ask before booking.  My entire say was filled with church youth group kids running rampant all over the hotel.  The kids stole my do not disturb sign, so I had a housekeeper who did not speak english at my door early in the am knocking on my door.   All hotel security did was stand around downstairs.The hotel itself was clean and recently renovated.  I hope to never stay here again.It was clean and the staff was friendly. But, I was staying in a Holiday Inn last night costing about half as much, and that was clean and the staff was friendly too. In fact, the Holiday Inn had a (much) better shower.Then there's wifi. I get that this is an amenity and everything, but McDonalds offers WiFi as a given. There was a time where it made sense to charge extra for WiFi--when no one understood what on earth it was. But now everything is wireless and there's just no excuse for charge $14/night to use it. I did. And I found out that the $14/night charge is only good for the one  device you signed up on, not for the whole room.Anyway; I'd stay here for $100/night, too much at $150/night.****UPDATE**** Mike Keisel, Director of Rooms for the Hyatt Regency got in touch with me about these issues. He was very sweet, and apologized for the original error and the poor service I received from the accounting department. He says he has contacted the managers of all parties involved, to be sure that they are corrected for future reference. The have also offered me compensation I feel is appropriate and even generous for the issues I had to endure. I view this matter as closed, and I will re-consider my decision not to stay with the Hyatt at next years con.Modern and luxurious.  The room was done in a grey/blue motif with granite topped tables and furniture.  The bed was very comfortable.  My room view was looking over convention center roofs and the expressway, but still, being on the upper floors is amazing and I loved looking out at night on the city.  In the remodel apparently every room was equipped with a spacious refrigerator, and there is plenty of in-room storage.  I really relaxed deeply and enjoyed this stay.  I would recommend the Hyatt to others. Other positives:- Very friendly staff; were bright and guest-centered.- If you need food, many in-hotel options.- Great to sit in the Big Bar on 2 and people-watch.  Also ran into interesting people on the elevator and had good conversations.  This is the host hotel for many conventions and also for some sports events at Nationwide Arena (also just down the block.)- Large-screen television.- Awesome bathroom.  Their interior designer should be proud of what they accomplished.- Easy connection to the convention center.  Very easy to navigate compared with similar cities like Indianapolis.- You are right on High Street so it is easy to get to OSU, the Short North, Clintonville, German Village, or other destinations.- Price was on the mark for a major downtown hotel.- Good Verizon 3G connection; I relied on my iPhone tether instead of paying for hotel WiFi.- Awesome windows and view as mentioned, and the window coverings also block out light well so you can sleep in if you would like. Some points for improvement:- Expensive parking - $12 to $25 per day depending on the option you choose.- Parking on Chestnut for $18 with in/out privileges means you will have to take two elevator rides and one escalator ride, as well as walk a good 4 blocks of ramps to get to your car.  The ramps are unheated.  If leaving after 10pm, you must stop at the hotel desk to get a paycard.- If self-parking, you're not allowed to unload in front of the hotel; you have to unload from the parking garage.  The turning circle in front of the hotel is congested and small.- Food at the Big Bar was a little bland and pricey.- You have to walk through the pool area to get to the workout room; no one was using either one because it wasn't very nice.  The machines were new, but someone had gotten the floor wet (making it unsafe to jump on a treadmill), and the cardio equipment seemed to be built for very tall people.- You do get an in-room fridge, but you have to bother the restaurant staff on the 2nd floor to use a microwave.  I was directed to talk to the Big Bar staff or the Market breakfast staff for this, and that made it awkward.Rooms are ok, though in my 2 personal stays here, I have never received the room type I'd requested.I think the high point was the valet driver stealing my keys and then lying about it (when I had just identified my keys with ALL keys/keychains present prior to him grabbing my car).  No apology from him, the valet mgr or the hotel itself. I had to pay to get my apartment rekeyed, for a new mail key, etc.  Nice pool, but no hot-tub.
review_content_80: Stayed Feb 2013.  I've stayed at many high-end hotels in almost every big city in the US and was surprised that this Hyatt in Columbus was one of the best service experiences I've ever had.  Hats off to the staff that just made my stay feel fantastic.  I will certainly return.Did not stay here but ate at the breakfast buffet for a business function.  Many food options to choose from.  Connected to the convention center, so conveniently locatedWhen my husband and I were in Columbus over MLK weekend, we decided to stay in a hotel for two nights rather than impose on some friends. I used Priceline and ended up with the Hyatt Regency for $43/night for a Saturday and Sunday night stay. Sweet!The reservation was under my name, but I was running a bit late to meet my husband at the hotel to check-in and he got restless. They nicely allowed him to check-in and we got a room on the 17th floor. The room had a nice view of downtown and Nationwide Arena. Bed was comfy which is always a plus. All and all, a nice, simple room. We were barely in it but to sleep or change clothes, so simple was fine with us.Parking is available in either a nearby garage ($12 per day at the Chestnut Street garage behind the Crowne Plaza) or a meter (only really an option if you are staying over a weekend). There is also valet, but I am not sure on the cost. The valets are also very helpful in hailing a cab which is easy as there are many lined up on Nationwide Boulevard near the hotel. Easy access to 670 and 315 make this hotel in a great location if you need to get around Columbus. Plus there are tons of bars, restaurants, and shops around the Arena and in the Short North that a car isn't even required.I would definitely stay at the Hyatt on a future trip to Columbus. Nice hotel in a good central Columbus location.No free internet access, really expensive parking depending on the day and freezing conference rooms. Really disappointing in 2011 to not be able to access wi-fi and have to pay $9.95 a day.So I normally don't stay at Hyatt hotels because I am a staunch Marriott fan.  However, had to stay here due to a company event and they booked the rooms.  Wasn't happy at all about my room.  Right away, the moment I walked into the "clean bathroom" my shoes were sticking to the floor.  You could see the marks from my shoes in whatever they are using on this floor (or not using) and it was annoying to have a sticky floor.  When I opened the closet I found three (yes three!) hangers, and I'm here for a week.  Had to call for a few more hangers.  Then, when I took out the iron and the ironing board I found that the iron didn't work well, leaked water all over my clothes, and would not steam.  Had to call again, this time for a replacement iron.  Once I got the new iron going I noticed that they were too cheap to put a proper ironing pad under the ironing board cover.  So I would iron my black shirt and see a waffle pattern from the ironing board!  Unbelievable.  I had to use those stupid little strip blankets they put at the base of the bed to put underneath the ironing board cover to properly iron my clothes.  The lamp on the desk is a solid arch lamp, so you can't adjust it out of the way if you are using a laptop, so basically had to shove it to the side and get it out of the way.  Do they ever actually use the rooms before they do this stuff?  One good things is that they finally have enough plugs for all the electronic devices we have now days.  I also had dinner in the one restaurant in the lobby and it was hugely overpriced for what you get.  It's my first night here, so I will post updates as it goes.Some places are saved by service.  The hotel is, as the French would say, "OK", but the people that work there are really nice which made my stay go from bummer to OK.  I don't understand why they bothered to put big LCD TVs in the room then have a non-HD signal though?  That seems really dumb.I was torn between 2 and 3 stars for this hotel. For the annual event I was attending, it was by far the best location I'd stayed at, and despite warnings about the crush at the elevators near mealtimes, I never had much trouble getting up to my eighth-floor room. We were next to the elevators but the noise wasn't bothersome. I was surprised they couldn't switch us from a two-doubles room to a king at a gaming convention, but c'est la vie.Huge downsides: ridiculous charges for internet. The event we were in town for did have free wireless codes, but we arrived a day early and had already wasted $20 on a hotspot card because the advertised internet price was $10 per DAY. The business center, where I briefly considered doing some last-minute printing, was riDICulously priced. I realize many of the bread-and-butter clientele of this place are probably corporate types who are expensing everything, but for the casual traveler this is absurd, especially when there's a fantastic FedEx Office with free wireless within three blocks, and a UPS store in the basement.Also, the pool, which is in the basement, is the saddest thing I have ever seen. The transition between the posh lobby and the dingy, dated Days Inn-level pool/fitness area is jarring, and I hope they will update it eventually. Seriously, a $150/night hotel without a hot tub? The heck?There was also reduced-cost parking available with in-out privileges about a block away, which was convenient and allowed me to run some errands for friends; there are cheaper if slightly less convenient lots in the immediate area, but hey, it's a downtown area, I can stomach paying for parking.While I appreciated the convenience of this hotel, I am much more likely to stay at the Crowne Plaza or the Hampton next year. Free breakfast, comparable parking, better pool (in the latter), and cheaper wireless are worth the slightly longer walk to me.Ooooh boy, is this a nice hotel or what? I've been to better Hyatts but even living up the street from this hotel, there's usually a weekend each year (normally during Ohayocon) where I just stay at this Hyatt. Yeah, it's close. Yeah, it's kinda expensive. Yeah, it's an awesome experience.Sure, it's comfortable and clean and the check-in is a breeze. The real deal here is the breakfast buffet. Get in on that jam if you can. Dee. Lish. Us. Go for the sausage gravy and biscuits- the best I've ever had. Done.Roomy, beautiful, right downtown- this is the only hotel in Columbus I've stayed and and truly loved.Not much on the room service menu. Nothing to eat in hotel or surrounding area late at night.  Rooms are great though.Note to any business travelers thinking of staying with the Hyatt Regency Columbus- There are many other hotels (Hilton, Renaissance, Sheraton) in the immediate vicinity- stay there!  Upon check in, I was told that my king room was not available, but I would be upgraded to a female business class room with a robe and make up mirror :(  I have also found hotel security to be slim, at 4 am, I had to listen to a belligerent man yelling in the hall and bouncing from wall to wall.  This morning, while walking to the convention center via the hotel, I found a man sleeping in the hotel 2nd floor, not far from the restaurant and bar.  This evening, I ordered room service and as I began to eat, a man began knocking at my door.  He was from engineering and wanted to fix something with the HVAC that was impacting other floors.  I felt uncomfortable with the situation and thought that the hotel should have notified me in advance.  Upon calling the manager, he seemed to want to rush me off of the phone and thanked me for my concern and wanted to make sure that I felt better now.  This was handled in a completely dismissive manner and I am extremely dissatisfied with feeling patronized.  In summary, stay at the Hilton or Renaissance if you need to be in Columbus!Stayed here last year and it was the worst experience of my life with a hotel. Came down for a girls volleyball tournament and wound up in the bells city tattoo and piercing convention . I don't expect the staff to wave me off during my phone conversation booking a room but a little hint like " are you coming for the tattoo and piercing convention at our hotel or the volleyball tournament at the convention center" I think I could have figured it out from there or at lease it begs for a question or 2. Check in was long and the desks were understaffed, the elevators are small and full the entire weekend. Oh and the crack valet staff made up of foreign students that probably don't hold a drivers license wrecked my car 10 minutes after I gave them the keys but didn't bother to tell me until I checked out 2 days later. That was a 3 week $5500 event ordeal after i only wanted a weekend experience. Parking is off site and a friend attending an event the next weekend had a similar situation with the valet staff.  This year we stayed at the New Hilton across the street. What a difference from the ancient, run down, overpriced, dump called the Hyatt on the corner. I had a chance to walk over from the convention center and spend some time looking around, its still the same issues. Restraunt still looks like a 1950's Manners, misspelled menu's, ect.  Friends stayed there but came over to the Hilton next door to have some drinks and were upset they didn't stay.  Do yourself a favor and get to the shining spot of hotels in downtime Columbus the New Hilton will impress you at every turn.Who's the bigger cheapskate:  The traveler who is unwilling to pay 9.95 for crappy internet serviceORThe hotel that talks about customer service and then decides to jam customers for internet service.Thank god for being able to get a connection from the Crowne Plaza across the street who understand what customer service is about.Very disappointing, and I would strongly recommend looking into the Westin (nearby) instead.  We paid $180 on Hotwire, and got a clean, neat but utterly average room.  The location is fine, but the rooms are really blah, as is the mundane lobby.  (Seriously: just go walk into the Westin lobby and compare--that's what we got on Hotwire last year.)  Plus, no free Wifi--they're living in the stone age.  The CLARION has free wifi!  The TV was perpendicular to the bed, there was no art on a blank wall, and they forgot the guest-services book in our room.  Won't be coming back.I was here recently for a hockey game with a big travel group.  The hotel was nice, staff was very friendly and accommodating, and is very close to the arena.  The biggest complaint I have about the rooms is that the sheets were a little scratchy.  The staff went out of their way to provide gluten free foods that I could eat when everyone else was eating their morning bagels.  They were SO helpful and gracious!

review_content: Beautiful hotel. Quick valet. (Although we would prefer to have our own parking; but it's not a big deal.)The rooms were quaint but sparse. No mini fridge? That's being a little too selective on amenities. Being that the rooms are tiny, the voices from the hallway are basically right in your ear.The bathroom was fantastic though! Everyone was polite.We booked on Hotwire and were assigned this hotel and we ended up happy with it, but we probably wouldn't purposely choose it again.Beautiful historic building, the lobby is truly beautiful. The rooms suck. Tiny - and I mean can-barely-skootch-around-the-bed itty bitty - musty, bright at night (the blinds cover only the middle of the window), thin walls, old loud plumbing that runs constantly. The bathroom is the highlight of the room, it's been updated (other than bad internal plumbing) and the shower is heavenly. The front desk staff are trained to check you in and nothing else. They really can't help you in any other way. They took two days to find a fax that other hotels usually have waiting for me. They were slow to get me help when the events staff failed me. They couldn't find boxes that I knew very well were there. Then they brought me an outgoing box, clearly marked. Ugh!The events staff truly stink. That is, if there is an events staff, I'm not really sure,  since I had to keep tracking people down for silly things like water service, a projector screen, and electricity. It took two hours for them to finally remove the dozen or so extra chairs lining the walls. No one checked on us, ever. I had to go back to the front desk several times to ask for more water.I also would not recommend the conference room because of the giant pole right in the middle of it.Parking is valet only and $25+ per day. There is a lot down the road, use it. Valet guys aren't that friendly and aren't quick to figure things out like needing a luggage cart or letting you know, as you wait forever, that they have come back with your car and parked it (running) around the corner where you can't see it. Fridge in room, no microwave. No free breakfast, overpriced cafe. Food OK, not exceptional or anything worth the price. All in all, a really expensive Meh. By the way, when the ballet is going, you can't get anywhere near the place.The lobby really is pretty.Definitely a historic building in its day which was renovated to some degree. Actually I would say the building itself has remained the same except the furniture which itself was very cute and trendy like the Westin or W brand. Booked this deal on hotwire, so the price was not too outrageous. We paid $24 for overnight valet (with in and out privileges). Service was definitely on par with what I would expect form a 4 star hotel. So friendly, helpful, take their time with you to tell you what's happening in the city, how to get there etc. We had change our first room because the air conditioner was too loud. The bed and pillows were ultra plush, slept like a baby. Hotel is also walkable to bus stations, restaurants, bars and a cool outdoor concert area. Had some extra time and went for a quick work out in the 24 hour gym area. There were maybe 10 treadmills and six ellipticals, vast array of weight and some exercise machines. They also give you complimentary headphones so you can sing eye of the tiger on your 99th mile on the treadmill. Sad there was no pool/jaccuzi. But, free starbucks coffee in the morning made me quickly forget that.Cordial front desk. The room is tiny but that is typical when you use Priceline bid. A wonderful view of a wall but again my Priceline bid was $75. Not going to complain.  Very comfortable bed, clean but small shower. This review is about 5 months old.Walls in the rooms are thin you can hear lots, hard to sleep peaceful unless u have a fan or TV left on. Bartenders at bar were not very friendly and we felt like we were a burden when we ordered a drink. Room service is extreamly over priced. A $4 charge for bottle water, should be complementary when u pay over $200 for a room.I had a great experience staying at this hotel last month. The staff at the reception desk were very friendly, and check in was easy. My room was average size and had a comfy king bed. The bathroom was nice and seemed like it had been renovated. I was having problems with the hair dryer in my room, so I called the concierge, and they brought me a new one within 10 minutes. Now that's good service!They have a small gym with a few treadmills, ellipticals, and weights. Towels and water bottles are provided in the gym which is so nice.Parking is valet. It was easy for check in, but when I was checking out, there was an event at the hotel, so I had to wait ~10 min for my car which was a little annoying.The hotel is in a great location, and if you want to explore downtown, you can hop on the CBUS, which is a free shuttle that runs on High St. I would definitely stay here again if I'm in the area.My stay at this hotel was great.  The check in staff was genuinely warm and friendly providing great information to add to my stay and make me feel welcome on my first trip to Columbus. The lobby is amazing. I was told there was free breakfast, but due to other plans, I didn't get to check it out, but would definitely look forward to that on another stay. I was surprisingly upgraded to a suite, which had a full living room area with a separate door to the bedroom area which I liked as it helped block more of the hallway noise.  Aesthetically, I felt the rooms could use some touches to make it softer and cozier.  The rooms had very high ceilings with plain square decor that made it feel a bit cold with the hard square room. For me, the space was way more room than I needed for my stay, and I didn't spend any time in the living room area.  I did enjoy the free bottled water!That said, the bed was amazingly comfortable and the shower had a Westin Heavenly Shower faucet that has two shower heads which was AMAZING.  I could have stayed in the shower forever.  So outside of the appearance of the room, it was actually a very comfortable stay. The room was also immaculately clean and in great shape. I was greeted at the door by staff politely as I was in and out of the hotel, and when it was time to head back to the airport, there was a cab ready to go.  I would very much stay here again!Just came back from a B-E-A-UTIFUL wedding, in which the reception was hosted at The Westin! The location and environment of this hotel was so elegant and classy. Everything has a grandeur look about it, especially the architecture of the historical building. The second floor layout is a little wonky though - someone can easily just walk through your event in order to get to their rooms. The food served was well prepared, and tasty enough considering they were serving 150+ plates!Overall, very impressed!COLUMBUS, OH: This is a lovely historic hotel that boasts nice architecture in the lobby and exterior.  The hallways to the rooms are wide and spacious and it has been renovated.The rooms are a bit small, unfortunately, with very plain furnishings and small bathrooms, unfortunately.  Also, there is absolutely no self-park option, valet only, which can be slow during a busy time.I have stayed at lots of Starwood properties over the years and while this historic building maybe one of the prettiest properties that I have visited it is definitely not the best. On the night of our arrival the air conditioning was not working and our tiny room was extremely warm. Maintenance attempted to open our window, but the latch was broken and it was unable to stay up. They did provide us with a small fan, but it didn't do much. The room was small and claustrophobic especially for the high price and the bathroom was one of the smallest hotel bathrooms I've ever seen. The staff was helpful and courteous, the location was okay, but I probably wouldn't choose this hotel again if I had other options in the area.Excellent hotel, location and staff.  They are a bit less Westin or W staff then I am used too.  Very Donald Trump. My Golden Retriever -Jake strutted through the lobby like a star politician.  Glam. And they upgraded us to a monster large presidential suits.  Woohoo.Lock your items up! My husband, mother and I upgraded to a 2 bedroom suite for the weekend.  We stayed here for a concert at LC Pavilion Friday February 6th and Saturday night Feb 7th.  After the show, we returned to a hotel room that had been robbed. My Cash, and jewelry were taken, my mothers cash was taken, and my husbands favorite watch was stolen. I will never stay at this hotel again. I would look very closely at your valet or housekeeping. Those individuals that knew what we had in our room, and when we would be gone! The front desk was very helpful and refunded our stay, but that doesn't put my hard earned money back in my purse, or my husbands special watch back on his wrist. I feel disgusted and violated. I will never stay at this Westin or any others again!Love the location. Easy drive to anywhere downtown Columbus. The hotel has a lovely flair to it. Great dining and a few nice small stores located inside.Hotel History: The place was built in 1896 very historic - so the style of that time period is women wearing Hula hoop dresses that were really wide.With that in mind the hallways for your arrival to your room are very wide. Yet we as humans were slightly smaller so the rooms were smaller.The Westin apparently bought it and tried to take it over and make it their own. NICE TRY Westin this is the worst attempt I have seen by this company in any cityThis hotel is not a 4 star as advertised by many online companies. More like 3I agree with Adam S  his review is spot on!This hotels lobby is cool and the staff very friendly.The furniture in the room is ok at best, the rooms are very small, the carpet needs upgrading in and out of the rooms and hallways, the bathrooms are fairly cool.Not too shabby.  Great service and accommodations, especially for the price.   The valet staff was very kind and helpful, especially when I just needed to grab things out of the car.  The Barista was my favorite.  I spent a lot of money there.  The hotel has a licensed starbucks stand.  The hotel breakfast is pretty decent.  $15 for the buffet.  Go hungry!  The shower stopped pumping hot water.  It was fixed in 5min.  It's like they actually wanted me to write a good yelp review.Beautiful lobby and friendly staff, and that's where the charm of this hotel ends. Yes, the rooms are small, but I accept that given the historic nature of the building. I'm more concerned with the paper thin walls and uncomfortable beds which was surprising given the "Heavenly Bed" thing. Maybe I just got unlucky with an Earthly Bed. I can clearly hear my neighbor's TV along with the fact that someone just took a shower. Last night it was conversation (not loud mind you, just two people talking.) This is probably the worst Westin I've ever stayed in outside of a bad one off the strip in Vegas. If you need the Starwood points, do your thang, but otherwise, you might think about going elsewhere.BTW, if you do stay here and are driving, there is ample parking within a block of the hotel that is less than half the price of the valet.I was assigned a preferred room with two beds. It was spacious for two people.Room was well equipped.Clean, comfortable beds, fridge,  gigantic shower head, bath robe, even mouth wash...lol..Starbucks Coffee and a plate of fruits???  Whoa i feel so special...first time i get a plate of fresh fruits in my hotel room, includes  raspberries and black berries. ..so fancy...:)My friend parked at a close by parking lot to save money on parking  (kinda inconvenient but save enough money to buy 2 margaritas...lol..;))Would've been perfect if free parking and wifi were included...My sister-in-law and I stayed at The Westin this past weekend to celebrate our birthdays. First we went to a Spa Day at Square One then we checked into our "suite." Overall the room was nice, included a treadmill and some workout equipment, but for $208 we expected to have at least a room with a view.. The beds slept well and the rooms were updated. We enjoyed room service at a reasonable cost in the morning and comfortable robes to lay around the room in. We valet parked overnight ($25) and took an Uber to the Short North. Uber was super cheap at $5 there and $5 back.Great room and hotel overall, probably wouldn't have spent the extra money for the "suite," but I would stay here again!We had a wonderful experience at the Westin. The staff is very friendly, and gives the impression they are happy to be helping you. (Jacob greeted us at the front desk and was so nice and helpful!) We had the chance to grab a snack and cocktail in the restaurant, which was also great. The bartender was able to suggest dishes that were vegan, which is always very appreciated.Ordered room service in the morning; pleasantly delivered, warm and as-ordered. Oh-and free upgrade on our room at check-in! Yes, rooms are small, but it's a beautiful historic building. Just no complaints about The Westin. :)So it sounds like the Westin Columbus is a historic building! Overall the staff is friendly, neighborhood is cute - just walking distance from the river and feels like a college town, very quiet. I stayed in the Deluxe Room, it's adequate...but fairly tight. You can't even fit a suitcase through when the bathroom door is open! But it was good enough for me, just one person staying for business. They charged for wifi, per device which was annoying and it wasn't a very strong connection. Lastly, room service was good - had a yummy breakfast sandwich, burger and chicken wrap while I was there. And it comes quickly!!
review_content_20: When it comes to urban travel, it is relatively easy to find old-fashioned grandness, historic properties, and beaux-arts enclaves that capture and charm their guests' imaginations.  In such a category, however, it's hard to find hotels that manage to embrace their historic nature while also maintaining satisfaction of each of the necessary tropes of luxury travel (compare a Ritz Carlton in downtown San Francisco to one on Half Moon Bay and the difference is blatantly clear) Columbus' Westin tries to strike a balance, and it does so with varying level of success depending on the amenity.  Having stayed in numerous older hotels, there is necessarily a curve on which they should be graded.  And even then, so far as Downtown Columbus hotels go, this one is the best.  It's not perfect, but it has its qualities.Unable to procure a bed and breakfast with availability outside of town it was necessary to "bite the bullet" and stay in the urban area.  The Former Great Southern Hotel channels the essence of historic Columbus - a neighborhood of refined mansions and neo-gothic mid-nineteenth century architecture.  With the passing decades many of the small estates have been supplanted by modern office buildings, but the handsome red-brick 1890s building remains.  It's a handsome structure, and its neo-baroque lobby (in spite of a few head-scratching juxtapositions from various renovations over the years) is very Ritz Carlton in style.  It's white marble with gilded railings and soaring skylight lends an aire of sophistication.  Check-in was pleasant and friendly, and by virtue of being an SPG member was instantly upgraded from a Deluxe Queen room to an Executive King Suite... worth double what they were charging... with free internet.  And 4:00 PM check out.  Perfect.The rooms, however, are cookie-cutter Westin - though that isn't a bad thing.  Comfortable, muted colors with traditional furnishings, they are pleasant places to stay.  However, they are a tad disappointing after taking in the impressive lobby.  My particular room looked into the interior courtyard (not terribly scenic) and possessed a slightly awkward layout - a very skinny sitting room with desk, television, and sofa, and a larger bedroom with king, second television, HUGE closet, and a very tiny (though well-equipped) bathroom containing granite countertops and a very nice shower.  I understand that each of the rooms possesses a unique layout with rather wide variation.  In my case, the slightly awkward layout was not a problem (having the whole thing to myself, it was a TON of space), and everything about it was extremely comfortable.  The "heavenly" bed lives up to its name, and the bathrobes unbelievably comfortable.  The complimentary toiletry items possess wonderful scents and textures, and the in-room wet bar actually possessed a decent champagne.The stay itself was very quiet the first night.  The second night a slight murmur was apparent, but the thicker walls (older hotels have their benefits) rendered the nigh peaceful nonetheless.  The next morning, however, the hallways on my floor were a bit of a mess... apparently there was a wedding and the guests were a tad soused.As far as other amenities, being an urban hotel in a historic building there is no pool (though the fitness center is very nice), and a focus on convention space (which are all VERY opulent for a four-star resort.)  The attached historic Southern Theater space, with its line-up of classical concerts, settles in perfectlyThe hotel restaurants will possess reviews of their own, but on the whole this Westin was a pleasant surprise.  The service was top-of-the-line five star caliber, the architecture of the public spaces opulent and extravagant, the rooms comfortable, well-equipped and welcoming (if a bit beige and lacking in character), and the value for the expense more than commensurate (they under-promise, but over deliver).  They earn each and every one of their four stars.  Should I find myself back in Columbus, I wouldn't be upset if I ended up staying here again.The friendly staff, nice workout room, and the historic property are the only things that keep this review from being 2 stars. While the front desk shared there was going to be a reception until midnight, they did not share the entire room would be vibrating from the music. Fortunately, we did not have our kids with us as that would have been miserable. My wife and I were out till 10:30, so we only had to deal with the intense noise for 90 minutes. I would expect a Westin property to convey at the time of booking that the noise level would be extremely high until midnight. We would have selected a different property. I would not stay here on the weekend unless you are part of the reception taking place. The staff did comp our breakfast which was nice, but we would have preferred peace and quiet in our room. Other reviews on the parking were helpful as we parked across the street for half the price of the hotel valet. If you are in Columbus for the weekend ask whether they are hosting a wedding reception and if they are stay elsewhere.I was so excited when we were able to book The Westin for our trip to Columbus for the Ohio State Michigan game.  Every Westin I have stayed at has been excellent and I love the heavenly beds.  So to the review.The good:Hotel lobby was stunning.  The intricate details along with the Christmas decor was beautiful.The staff was extremely friendly and very helpful.The bar had great bartenders and fabulous drinks.The location was great.  It was close to the highways, restaurants, nightlife and the stadium (3 miles approx)The OK:The elevators were old and rickety.The rooms were extremely small and the bathrooms were completely outdated.Once you reached the hotel room floors, the floors were plain and dark.With all that said.  I am a huge fan of Westin hotels and I am really big on NICE rooms.  However, for spending 150+ per night, it was definitely not somewhere I would want to stay again unless I could get a larger room.  If you don't care about rooms, this is an excellent place to stay.I'm okay with the small rooms...its a historical hotel. The fixtures are nice...the rainfall shower head is a plus. Room service was fine. Meal was passable. What has earned two stars from me was that happened at the beginning of my stay and what happened at the end of my stay. As I was checking in to the hotel, I was assisted by a very sweet young man who just couldn't have been more polite. However, there was another person working at the reception desk who lacked all of the skill this young man had. In fact, her rudeness and lack of customer service skills were so obvious that I was distracted from my pleasant experience to witness her being sarcastic and nasty to a customer whose key card wasn't working. She told the woman the card wasn't working because she must have had it next to her phone. The customer told her the card was not next to the phone, it was in her handbag...to which the young lady replied it must have been a magnetic clip on the customer's purse. The customer said there was no magnetic closure. The young lady continued to challenge her. WHY would she argue about how the problem came to be? Just fix the problem, take care of the customer and get her a new card. After she made a new key card and the customer left the front desk, she made sarcastic and rude comments about the customer. It was shocking. This is clearly a person who does not belong in a position of serving customers. Ever. Her behavior was distracting and inappropriate.At the end of my stay, I was awakened by the fire alarm at 6:00am...it sounded for about 35 seconds then ceased. Just enough to ensure I wouldn't be getting back to sleep any time soon...as is was leaving, it took 10 minutes to get a hold of the valet. The car was brought around quickly, but there was nobody at the phone. I understand mornings are busy, but staff the shift adequately. The housekeeping staff does a good job in the rooms, so kudos to them.Sad to say, but I won't be back.Room was very small, as in the bathroom was the size of a closet. However, it was in good repair and served its purpose. Fairly quiet through the night even though we were close to the elevator. Rick at the front desk was extremely professional and kind. The architecture of this downtown hotel is gorgeous and it's close to the Cbus line that basically allows you access to all the major districts in the city (Arena, Brewery, Short North, etc)Not impressed. I bought a "traditional queen"/standard room for one night for my wife and I's 5yr wedding anniversary and it cost me $200 plus another $24 for overnight parking. The outside of the hotel looked old and historic so I thought it would be a neat stay, but the interior was all modern and updated which lost its historic charm. The room was one of the smallest ive stayed in and same here, no old world charm. Nice fixtures in the bathroom and a comfy bed but that's the only perk it had. The walls are super thin and we heard a party going on all night down the hall. After checking out we decided to get our complimentary breakfast. They had a decent buffet set up so we helped our selves. After finishing the meal they handed us a $35 bill for breakfast and pointed out that the free breakfast was the counter with the Cheerios and yogurt on it. For a place that charges so much, I wasn't expecting to be nickeled and dimed. Not a good experience for us and we won't be wasting our money here again.Attended a beautiful wedding here last weekend.  It was held in the ballroom.  Parking was nearby in lots.  Could have parked in the open Westin lot for $6.  Parked in covered parking across the street for $3.  The lobby is beautiful.  Nice architectural details.  The wedding was on the second floor.  As we waited outside the ballroom, there was chilled cucumber and lemon water available.  The ballroom was set up half for the ceremony and half for the sit-down reception.  It was a small wedding with maybe 120 guests.  One note:  during the wedding the a/c was quite noisy at times.  Once the ceremony was over, we were instructed to leave the ballroom while they set up for the reception.  There was a nice bar they had set up in the area outside the ballroom.  We then returned to the ballroom (it had beautiful stain-glassed windows) where we had a sit-down reception.  Service was excellent (though one of the servers seemed a bit impatient when a guest had removed her name card to save.  The name card indicated her protein preference.)  I had the salmon which can be iffy of a banquet, but it was moist and delicious.  Hubby had the steak which was a large portion - he thought it was okay.  Bottom-line:  Venue was beautiful but beware of the noisy a/c in the ballroom.  Food was delicious.  Park across the street in the covered lot.Spent the weekend here. Friday n Saturday night. Had the best customer service I've ever had. The hotel was clean. Food was awesome. The staff treated us like royalty. I didn't wanna leave. My husband n daughter n I enjoyed our stay so much!!! Can't wait to stay here again!! The hotel is beautiful and the history makes it more of an experience. Thanks to all the staff for making our spring weekend get away so wonderful. Every single one of the staff from the valet to the front desk to the room service. We had not one complaint!! Best stay I've ever had in a hotel.Stayed here for two consecutive nights, one by choice and the other due to a cancelled flight.  The staff are quite lovely and helpful.  They extended a special rate for a wedding to the unexpected stay.  They "de feathered" a room to accommodate a feather allergy.  The property itself is very historic and beautiful.  The rooms have been updated as best as they could given the age of the building, but do show some signs of wear and tear.  Room service has Jeni's ice cream!  The location is pretty good if you don't mind walking. You are 15mins by foot to german village and 25mins to the short north and arena district.  Ubers aplenty are minutes away for those in heals or the non walking crowd.  I think the room rates are pretty reasonable too.We enjoyed our stay at The Westin Columbus. I read reviews that said the rooms were small. We stayed in a guest room that looked twice as large as shown in some reviewers pictures. The bathroom was small but I liked the rain-style shower head and we had plenty of towels and a nice sized closet. I loved the classic minimalist design. I would describe it as a 1960's kind of "Mad Men" style. I thought the hotel was beautiful, including the rooms.Buyer Beware!  Booked this hotel for a corporate meeting and discovered that their cancellation policy is not industry standard!  Looks like they are trying to make money anyway they can.  Be very very careful when dealing with this hotelI stay at a lot of Marriott and Starwood properties for work and pleasure.  The hotel itself is rather nice with the lobby being quite picturesque but the check in experience could be improved.  The person checking really only checked me in.  She did not talk about breakfast, wifi, parking etc.  The room itself is nothing to write home about.  There are very few outlets beside the one by one of the night stands which has a two outlet chargeport and a few by the business desk.  Against the wall there really are not outlets for ironing and the lights switch in the bathroom is hidden behind the towels.  The walls are paper thin and you can hear others talking.  The air conditioning unit is quite loud and will wake you up in the night.If I had a choice I would probably stay at the Hilton where my colleagues are staying at as it is a much newer hotel and closer to the nightlife.I stayed 1 night at this hotel for a wedding. The facilities were beautiful and I really enjoyed my stay (ballroom was very classy as was the hotel bar). One thing that really set them apart... I accidentally left my suit and dress shirt in my room closet and flew back to Chicago! I immediately contacted the hotel and got a very prompt response from Housekeeping/Lost & Found. Shiran Wijayaratyn, the Executive Housekeeper, took ownership, found my belongings and called me back immediately to get my address to send it back. He was very on top of it and never bothered to ask for payment to ship it back (which would have been reasonable). I was extremely impressed because I have not had this same experience at other hotels!!! (I had the exact opposite experience actually when my wife left something at a hotel last month) I really felt like Shiran went above and beyond... even little things like including several "white tea towelettes" in the package. Great service and I would highly recommend.Thank you very much!!!Staff is very friendly and the hotel is clean. The workout room is awesome for a hotel minus the fact that it's in the basement. The king room is pretty nice, pretty much a 4-star room. Got stuck one night in a "Queen Cozy", that is NOT a 4-star room. It was cramped and not well appointed, the shower leaked onto the floor, the TV didn't have a picture and the fridge wouldn't turn on. Valet is very prompt and once again, staff and management do their very best to accommodate your needs working with a very dated property. Honestly, despite the staff and excellent service, I would not stay here again. There are other hotels in Columbus that are 3-4 stars that are nicer, newer and closer to bars and restaurants. Kind of surprised Westin puts their name on this. Only giving 3 stars because of the staff. The property itself deserves about 1.5 stars. I like to visit historical landmarks, not stay in them.As far as fanciness goes, the Westin is certainly fancy. Walking in, looking at the marble tile and the high ceilings, you are overcome with a sense of grandeur.And that's about the only decent thing about the Westin.The rooms are small and cramped. There are noises in the creaky old walls. Visible pipes mar a complete look in some of the older rooms. The breakfast is expensive and overcooked.I was sorely disappointed in the Westin, partly because it seemed so nice when I first walked in. it's as if they put all of their effort into getting you to check in, and then didn't care what happened after that.Rooms are so dark and furniture so old. Anything other than lobby is bad quality. Especially shower...I had my wedding at the Westin in August 2013. My husband and I fell in love with the ballroom and knew it was the place.Overall, the experience was to be expected. Planning was stressful, but the Westin did what they could to help. Planning our menu was simple enough, and the staff (Lindsey Bruce, in particular) took care of all of the day-of coordination needed at the Westin, which was a huge relief. My only complaints surround small details that I would've liked done better, which I won't get into detail here. If you're thinking of the Westin for a wedding location feel free to message me and I'm happy to share. My two major complaints that I'll share here regarding their wedding planning services:1.) Our wedding coordinator was supposed to be there throughout the duration of the reception. She did ask me at 10 pm if she could leave, and I did say it was fine. I wasn't in the mood to get into a contractual argument with anyone on the day of my wedding, but I found that request entirely unprofessional. She had a contractual obligation, and should have known better than to ask for an out on the day of.2.) The Westin's wedding planning services do not provide much support with regard to giving you ideas on how to use the space. If you ask for photos of prior weddings they're happy to provide them. This resulted in several things being done on the day of our wedding that I (unfortunately) assumed would be done. For example, the lighting was not turned down when my husband and I had our first dance, which resulted in a less romantic dance.With regard to accommodations, I was happy with the Bridal Suite. I mean...it was the Bridal Suite, I can't really complain. I was disappointed that the day of my wedding we didn't have a turn down service so that the room looked clean and ready for some photographs we had taken (then again, I'm guessing they wanted to stay out of our way). Another complaint regarding rooms, my mom who really wanted to be on the same floor as me, was put into a closet of a hotel room. She was okay with it, I wasn't. With regard to booking, Lindsey and the Westin were very generous in their willingness to keep our blocked rooms open to our guests for an extended period of time; we did have to make this request, however Lindsey absolutely kept up with us to let us know our deadline was approaching. In addition, they were very accommodating with making reservations, and none of our guests had any complaints with regard to how they were treated during booking or checkout. The hotel did lose one or two reservations for some of our wedding guests, but promptly fixed the issue without complaint or fanfare, so no issues there truly.I will say this, given the fact that I had this massive idea of how lovely my wedding day was going to be, the Westin DID live up to that expectation. I have had nothing but raving reviews regarding how stunning and lovely our reception was.Front desk unable (or unwilling) to make a reservation in person and had us call the reservations line. We called and it didn't go through. Eventually someone checked us in. It took so long to check-in that the kitchen closed at the restaurant. Very unhelpful and disappointed after seeing such a pretty lobby. Subpar rooms and currently listening to really loud music from a wedding. Disappointed, hungry and hoping we don't get charged twice.This is lengthy but I promise you it is worth reading through.My husband and I booked a one night stay at this hotel on our way back to Canada from Arizona. We booked the King Corner suite at a rate of $339.00 Upon arrival, we pulled into the valet area at the front of the hotel. Three valets were standing on the sidewalk together. When we stopped, one came over to speak with my husband who was driving. I remained in the front passenger seat with the two remaining valets on the sidewalk to my right, about two feet from me.The valet told my husband he would have to park the truck and our trailer himself due to liability about the trailer. That wasn't a problem for us and the hotel parking lot was right next to the hotel. I waited for the valets on the sidewalk to come open my door and offer assistance. One had disappeared, and the third stood pecking on his cellphone, ignoring me.I gave up waiting, and got out myself, after swinging open a heavy door, struggling with a squirming dog and a huge loaded bag, and managing  to shove the door shut with my body and step up onto the sidewalk. Only then did the 'valet' look up from his cell phone, and mumble a half-hearted "Welcome to the Westin". I asked him why he didn't do anything and he mumbled something about "not being sure I was staying".Really??? He was two feet from me and the second I clicked the door handle, it was obvious I was getting out. I have never experienced such insolence and disrespect from any hotel employee, and it was a very disappointing and negative first impression of this hotel. He then made some lame offer of helping, so I said not to bother, I didn't want to interrupt any of his cell phone use. I turned and walked in the hotel.Before I tell you what happened next, I will say we were driving our 2012 Dodge Ram which we keep excellently maintained. These vehicle are equipped with technology that constantly monitors  tire pressure,  and lets you know immediately if there are any issues. We had just driven over 2000 miles with no vehicle issues of any kind, and it remained so right until my husband parked it in the Westin lot for the night.The next morning, we went to the truck and surprise, surprise....someone had let the air out of both our front tires. We filled the tires and drove back to Canada with no more tire issues.No, we did not see the valet deflate our tires. But given the facts I have outlined above, what are the odds the air oozed out of our front tires for any other reason than a deliberate act?We had just stayed overnight at four other hotels, and nothing happened. But after a confrontation with the Westin valet, this happens. Nice.If you are brave enough to consider staying at this hotel after reading this, I suggest you prepare to 'bow and scrape' to the staff member, no matter how poorly you are treated. Your vehicle might be attacked, or worse.Our total bill for this experience cost us $585.53 including the restaurant tab. You decide if you want to take a chance. Plus, when my husband checked out, he made a point of telling the concierge that we will never be back to any Westin, and as of this writing, no one from the Westin has contacted us.The lobby was beautiful and the staff nice, but for the price, not worth it.  Small room, plus - and this is why the one star - $10 a day for wifi?!? As my friend put it, "what kind of guest-respecting hotel doesn't have free wifi in 2014!?"  Agree.  I have traveled to dozens of cities and over fifty countries, and I just feel this place is over-priced and trying on nickel and diming the customer. Plus, even in some of  poorest places in the world at least offer free wifi.
review_content_40: Westin Columbus touts itself as the top,shelf hotel in C-Bus but in reality they have a long way to go to reach 4 or 5 star status. First. I have been staying at the Westin for several years in premium rooms and suites and there are no mini bars. What?????Second, the bar at the hotel closes at 12 pm. Huh?Third, the rooms have plastic cups in the bathrooms EVEN IN THE SUITES! And the rest of the amenities are nonexistent. Really, the "Suite" is just a really big corner room. I won't talk about the restaurant because that isI got to say I stay at A lot of Hotels. The Weston in Columbus is a horrible rip off.Free breakfast....nope. $15.99 Small rooms Yes! Free wifi nope...$7.99 per night. Free valet nope. $24 a night! If you plan on coming to Columbus ohio please look around there are a lot of good hotels at much better rates.This hotel was listed as a 4-star establishment when we booked it online, but I don't think it fits the bill. Lets start out with the positives. The bed was comfy, the little leaf shaped soaps made me smile, and the water was complimentary, along with coffee and tea from starbucks, which you could brew in your room. On the other hand, the room was a bit small and the decor was minimal and shabby. I expected more from a Westin in that department. Oh, and the pillows were awful and uncomfortable. I tossed and turned all night because of them. The parking situation was also not very likable - $20 to park overnight in a lot adjacent to the property. The spots are VERY small and hard to get in and out of, and you are almost certain to leave with an extra scratch or dent on your car, because the spaces are so tight.With the $99 per night deal from Hotels.com it is really hard to go wrong with the Westin. The check-in/check-out was fast and pleasant. The room was very clean and up to date. They also have a very lovely green tea soap/shampoo/lotion in each and every room.The only bad thing about this hotel is that the rooms are very small. However, I do not let the size of a hotel room detract from the good things because I dont really plan on spending a lot of time in my hotel room. However, if I was staying somewhere for a week or two I might want a larger room.We arrived at the hotel around 2pm and had no trouble with an early check-in. In fact we were given a room upgrade for no apparent reason, even after I requested to have 2 beds instead of the king bed that was originally assigned. The check-in staff couldn't have been more accommodating.The only overnight parking option through the hotel is $20 valet. I found a spot in a small lot across the Main and High Streets intersection for only $5 per day. I think this is just a weekend deal though, as the price was on a temporary sign.The public spaces of the hotel are very historic and well maintained. Our room on the 6th floor was very spacious and clean. The bathroom was the one place that could use a little work. The bathtub wasn't draining well and it left a puddle of water at your feet when showering. Plus there was no venting fan, so the steam would quickly build up in the bathroom.The workout room is in the basement. It is well stocked with equipment, water, and towels. The only problem I had was the temperature was set to 70 degrees, which is warmer than I keep my own house. This is a little too warm for a workout without a fan. There is no pool at this hotel.The location of the hotel is in the business district of Columbus, near the Courthouse. During our Saturday stay there seemed to be very little going on around the hotel. There was very little that we could have walked to.Overall we had a nice stay, but I think I'd consider other options on a return visit.Nice little hotel. This hotel is in a historic building (built circa 1890's) and has everything that you want in a hotel: nice bar, friendly staff, and high-quality rooms.We stayed here for a wedding in Columbus which, conveniently, was also held at the hotel ballroom. Upon arrival, we found the hotel staff to be incredibly friendly and welcoming to Columbus. With room service, the staff was just as friendly and polite.The hotel bar is solid too. They have a great selection of draft beers (Goose Island) and ample space (at the bar; high top tables; dining tables) for large numbers of people.The rooms are somewhat small, and the shower heads (yes, two!) were fantastic. The gym (in the basement) is nice enough with 4 treadmills, free weights, machine weights, and a few bikes/elliptical machines. The wedding venue in the ballroom (3rd floor) had high ceilings and made for a great party.The only downside, however, is the $20/day parking (even self-parking) but that is almost to be expected at any downtown city hotel.Reservations with the wedding planner not favorable. The hotel staff are not able to plan for you to enjoy the stay on the same floor even though it was planned months in advance, not to mention the detailed discussions from the mother of the bride. Valet was horrible upon arrival and continues to be rude and not welcoming (I only hope they do not park my vehicle in the less than reputable places in the area. Check in with staff was almost longer than the trip. They were clearly not equipped with knowledge of how to work the front desk and people skills. The bar/restaurant lacks at the minimum to provide good olives for a lack luster martini. Room size... Thin walls... Annoying in room AC... Poor lighting everywhere in the establishment... And in addition they cram in a desk with a visible power strip leaves the establishment far less from appealing.Just arrived today as the complimentary Happy Hour was ending. Checked in, and went to grab a workout. When I got back to the room, the hotel had left a complimentary welcome gift of fruit. Very unexpected, and much appreciated. Thank you Brian Crooks for getting my stay off to a good start!I love this hotel. As a resident/native of Columbus, I'm not well versed on its hotels, though I do my share of traveling outside of the 'bus. I have had the occasion to stay here, though, when I was living in Akron and my parents' house was undergoing massive renovation.
