It's always been relatively affordable in spite of the grandeur, and allows dogs! Anyway, if you're a local, don't discount the Westin. It has a lot going for it besides hotel rooms.Let's talk about events. I've attended a variety of events here (even one with Yelp!), including weddings, networking receptions, etc. I've never planned an event with them, but they must make it easy, because it pops up on my social calendar as a venue quite a bit. The lobby area is gorgeous. It feels grand, and historical. Back in the day, we knew this hotel as "the Great Southern" and the Westin has been respectful of its history. All the weddings I've attended here have imparted a similar elegance. One reception room I was in didn't even need any decorations, it was all mirrors and filigree. My most recent experience here was a networking event with the Columbus Young Professionals-- a little happy hour with snacks and cash bar in the lobby (not the hotel bar, Thurber's, but that is nice too). Afterwards, we all had tickets to the Columbus Symphony, performing in the attached Great Southern theater. This is probably my favorite theater in Columbus (though the Ohio is very, very close). It feels way more intimate than the Palace or the Ohio. It's a tall space, with at least three tiers of seating. There's really not a bad seat in the house. Careful, though, the seats at the top are on a very steep incline!Locals, I want you to think of the Westin as a non-contrived entertainment complex. Catch the symphony or a play, enjoy the grand lobby, grab cocktails at Thurber's (or, there's lots of great dining just steps away-- Sidebar 122, De Novo), and if the night is going REALLY well, grab a room.If you're looking for a dog friendly hotel in the Columbus area, this is defintely your place to stay. On a whim, my husband and I decided to take our dog on a road trip to go visit my brother at OSU. Never having stayed with our dog in a hotel, I was a bit nervous despite having spoke with the hotel manager to confirm that it was in fact okay to bring our dog. So, it was an awesome comfort to see that the Westin literally had a Welcome mat rolled out for the pooches in the form of a water bowl and treats right at the front door. The staff was incredibly nice, and even gave us a map of the dog parks in the area (note: there is a nice dog park about 15 mintues away, you just need to cross some kind of sketchy train tracks if you're going on foot). They even brought up an extra comforter and blankets to make a dog bed.The rooms could use a bit of a face lift, but I'm going to complain since the rooms were a pretty decent size. Our standard room had a sitting area/living room with a separate bedroom/bathroom area. The downtown area is pretty quiet but German Village is only a few minutes drive away, and the Brewery District is in walking distance. We'd defintely stay here again.Columbus to me is the city of new. New buildings, new restaurants, clean streets, etc. So walking into this place I expected the same, especially with the Westin name attached. The lobby is nice, the concierge, doormen, cleaning staff, incredibly friendly. But paying $199 on a weeknight I expect a little more. Also, having the W Hotel as your counterpart I expect more. Being in the lobby, I expected more. Walking into my room I thought, well... This is it? Now don't get me wrong, I am NOT below staying at a Holiday Inn or other comparable hotel, but when I pay more I expect more. The room looked old and almost looked identical, if not a little worse than a Holiday Inn or 3 star hotel would look, compared to this "4 star hotel." I was just really surprised, especially staying at a W where the rooms are SO nice and maybe the same price or a tad more. Plus, I've actually stayed at the Westin in Pittsburgh and the rooms are nicer than this one and I bet you the Pgh one is older!I did think it was cool that they will give you work out clothes, socks and shoes for a $5 rental fee. How many times have you gone to a hotel and either forgot one work out item or all them (me, me!). It's a little weird wearing work out gear others have worn, but I hope (and PRAY) they launder it with high quality chemicals. Maybe that's where all the money is going!!!!I've stayed in small, space efficient hotel rooms and this one was *not* one of those. I've also stayed in other Westin and "W" hotels before and this place could have fooled me. The $199 rate during the week did not match the quality I was expecting from the Westin name. The lobby itself made me think of a lot of Cleveland's downtown hotels--rich historic charm, gorgeous detail. But as soon as I stepped into my room I was insta-disappointed. Not only was the room tiny, but the space was just not utilized well. On top of that, the decor could have used some upgrades. The bathroom, on the other hand, was small but had great amenities like a walk-in, double shower head and with a chic, upgraded look. Another plus was the super, fluffy, awesome bed! It felt clean, cozy and like I could stay in it forever. Not that I really had a lot of extra time on my hands but I was a little disappointed there was no steam room, pool, nothing. Although, on the plus side there was a 24/7 access gym with lots of weights, etc. Even one of the employees was complaining about this location in comparisons to Westins elsewhere. Sheesh!I was so excited to stay at the Westin for my wedding (September, 2013) and to reserve it for my guests. It's so beautiful and in a great location! However, the Westin dropped the ball in nearly every way.A month before the wedding I was told that only 4 rooms (7 nights total) had been booked in our block and that they were going to open up the other rooms (per our agreement that whatever rooms weren't filled by August 31st would be opened back to the public.) That number seemed low but I figured our out-of-town guests were making their own plans. It was disappointing because had we gotten to 10 nights, our suite would have been free.10 days before our event, I called in to check the reservations I had made. Friday for two adjoining rooms so that my bridesmaids could stay with me and we would have space to get ready the next morning. Saturday, the bridal suite and another room for our DJ. I was told that I only had one room for Friday night and that the hotel was full. He kept telling me there was nothing he could do. I had to pressure the young man on the phone to put me in contact with Daniel Nelson who had booked our room block to figure it out. Thankfully, Daniel was very helpful and switched things around to rectify the situation (Only reason they got 2 stars instead of 1!)When we arrived on Friday there was not a iPod dock in the room as we had been promised. When I called down to the front desk they again said there was nothing they could do. Finally, I asked them to provide the Wifi for free so that we could stream the wedding day playlist through my computer instead.Saturday morning was spent getting ready and having a blast with my sisters and my mom and my bridesmaids. We put together all of our food and trash into a bag by the door and got all the towels into a pile. My maid-of-honor stopped by the front desk and let them know we had left so that they could go clean the room before my husband and I came back that night. Later that night, as the reception was winding down, my oldest sister called the Westin to insure the room would be ready.My husband and I showed up to our hotel room on our wedding night, SO excited to celebrate. We walked into our room and my jaw dropped. Bag of trash still by the door, bed unmade with the dirty sheets on, damp towels still in a pile in the bathroom, no clean glassware, and no bottle of champagne as we ordered.My husband went down to the front desk, where it took 20 minutes to get someone free to come upstairs and rectify the situation. But, because housekeeping was gone, our room wasn't cleaned at all, just new sheets put on. It didn't ruin our wedding, because well we got married! But it definitely ended the night on a bad note.To top it off, I was complaining to my siblings/laughing about the room and they shared with me that when they tried to book a room in JULY they were told our room block was full. (Remember, we apparently only booked 4 rooms by August 1st, plus we were promised that if our room block filled they would add more rooms.) We talked to a number of out-of-town guests who were also told the block was full before the required book-by-date. In all, we would have had 16 total nights booked and received the wedding suite free on Friday and Saturday.So, I e-mailed the Westin and explained the situation. They apologized and said that they had uncovered some housekeepers submitting false information and they were dismissed. They also acknowledged that there was transition in their sales department that likely led to the miscommunication about my room block. They then asked what they could do to rectify the situation. I stated that in my opinion, I should be reimbursed the cost for the adjoined rooms on Friday and the bridal suite on Friday & Saturday, my though process was this: Had my guests been able to book their rooms, I would have received the Bridal Suite for no cost per our contract anyway. And then to rectify the housekeeping issue on our wedding night, they should have reimbursed my cost for the adjoined room on Friday.After I made that request I never heard back from the Westin again. (Shocking. We'll give you whatever you want... except if you ask us for something we don't want to give you, then we'll just ignore you.)I was just talking to a friend about possibly having her rehearsal dinner and room block there and it made me upset all over again, that I decided I needed to write a Yelp! review to prevent anyone else from making the mistake of trusting details of their big day to the Westin!Its ok, just ok. Not the best, but ok.For being a Westin Hotel I was expecting better. It is an old building, but even the rooms are not as luxurious as other Westins. I will say the staff was friendly and very accommodating. For the price they charge, there are other hotels close by that you will probably get more for your buck. Its ok, just ok, Not the best, but ok!!!!I've been here twice for family weddings and the venue/hotel was great. The staff were so friendly and showed us where we had to be be each time. We had more than enough space for both weddings and it was nice that the guests could leave the room when it got too hot or loud.We often stay at Westin hotels because we travel with our small miniature poodle and Westin accepts pets. This week I needed to be in Columbus and my husband and dog came with me and I booked this Westin in Columbus. Such a disappointment! The room is very small, not to mention the bathroom and the carpet is old and dirty. Same for the carpet in the hallway. The bathroom has a smell of old wet towels. We always like to eat in the hotel so we are not far from our dog (another reason we like to stay at Westin Hotels, there is always a good restaurant in the building). The food at this hotel, however, was far from acceptable. My baked potato was cold and even the room temperature butter did not melt and my husband's steak salad was almost uneatable. The internet (they charged $9.95 per day) was terrible - slow and went in and out. I am not sure how Westin can claim this hotel - it is so different from all the others we have stayed at. The only good thing was that the staff was very friendly and helpful. I would not recommend this hotel for anyone who is used to the usual comfort of Westin hotels. In fact, not sure about staying at other Westin's after this experience.Nice room and bran new everything. Even though it was an older hotel and the rooms are a little small they ere decorated nicely and made you feel comfortable. It was upscale and nice. You get Starbucks coffee to brew in your rooms and little to go cups.This hotel is really a mixed bag, depending on what you are looking for. I'll break it down:Check in/out experience - Overall check in experience wasn't great. Service rep didn;t really know what was or wasn;t included in either my rate, or Platinum level benefits.Rooms - rooms can be either a decent size or pretty small. All of them feel very dated and in need of a refurbishment. I generally have a socks on policy at most hotels but this felt more like socks and shoes would be the safer option. Lights were often not working and powerstrip plug sockets just give everything a tacky feeling.Gym - the gym is great as I have only every been in there with one other user. They have abunch of cardio equipment (treadmills, bikes, elipticals) and so good weights (free weights from 5lb to 50lb and a life fitness fit 3 machine which is great for unassisted benchpressing).New Balance gymwear - As per my gym comments, the New Balance gear that you can borrow seemed brand new (I think people just don't work out around here). I forgot my gymwear one week and had to borrow and for $5 for the week, its a great dealFood/bar - food was ok. I had the lamb shank one time which was definitely pre cooked. The bar had zero atmosphere but friendly bar staffLocation - Can feel a little sketchy as it is near the courts - mainly a bunch of derelict storefronts with the exception of bail bondsmen.Cab situation - generally good with a cab usually waitingIf you are SPG, I would recommend the Sheraton down the street insteadLoved room. Parking is a fortune. $25. Was ok for bar. Prob wouldnt stay again with parking issue. I noted that after thr fact comment was added. However valet parker did not mention this and its still a sticker sdd on thats not able to be weighed n in advsnce when choosing a location.Nice, unique, highly historic property. My stay was three nights on business. - Not really the greatest location -- not really walkable to any desirable locales- Parking is quite pricey (even self parking)- The property is "historic" and you will feel this in your rooms--very old-school, florally, non-modern- Good customer service- Manager left a really nice note, coupon and fruit basket in my room upon arrival -- a greatly appreciated special touch.- One thing (for me) almost worth a Yelp star off -- using flat sheets when fitted sheets should be used -- you roll over one time and the sheet comes off under you!
review_content_60: I was here on business a few months ago and the check-in staff seemed a bit off of their game. However, the rooms were clean and our catered food was good. The hotel is located right downtown, so it's a good location, but they only have outdoor parking from what I experienced and no parking garage.You don't want to stay here. If you have another option, go there. This hotel may be high class but the staff is rude and not helpful. The waiters are rude. They got basically everything wrong for my sisters bridal suite on her wedding. I do not recommend this hotel.Extremely nice facility but very rude night time workers. We encountered two awful people (the bartender and the front desk attendant) when we came to check in on a Friday night. The day staff was lovely but I won't be back after encountering their night time workers and I am a gold member with SPG so I've seen a lot of hotels.Great staff, AMAZING bed, and charming aesthetics. Starwood is the way to go. But as for those reviewers who are bashing this hotel, they clearly didn't do their homework and have no appreciation for the past.We were lucky enough to first get a Hotwire rate of $65 a night (plus tax)!Then lucky enough to ask if we could upgrade from a Queen to a king and got a suite ($300+ at least)! Very nice and helpful staff. So our suite was a living room with TV, couch, side chair, mini bar, and coat closet, bathroom, and bedroom with TV, desk, dresser, and closet. Bathroom was on the smaller size, but the rooms felt plenty big esp. for a historic building. Bed is amazing. Great shower head. Calm and comfortable. Love the white tea toiletries and scent in the lobby! Amazing lobby. Little street traffic noisy and heater noisy in the rooms. Wear and tear here and there. No oatmeal on the room service menu. And $20 for parking a night. Not so great.THIS is a Westin? Methinks not so super duper. I'm glad I at least earned some SPG points for this stay...otherwise, I'd be pretty disappointed. On my last trip to Columbus, I selected this Westin to be my one night "home away from home." Unfortunately, my home would be much preferable to this...even with one million cats, a needy dog, laundry piles and a buncha lousy neighbors. Yes, still preferable!The room was so...SMALL. Like very, very teensy small with a desk jammed in and an itty bitty bathroom. No room to breathe. The bed was lumpy, the air vents were loud and I left a grumpy camper. NEXT! I stay at the Hampton in Short North from now on. Better neighborhood, more room to wiggle.Yikes! Not at all what I was looking for. Not what I expected from a Westin either. I guess I should have looked at the pictures and reviews better. Tired rooms, dark hallways; we checked in, walked in and out of the room and headed to another hotel. The staff was apologetic and informed me that this was a historical hotel; thus the older style.The staff and manager were really friendly at check in and gave us a great room upgrade. Sadly however, the quality of the rooms has really declined these last few years. Our room was not cleaned two days in a row, which was a real bummer and the furniture was banged up and stained. We love Starwood Resorts, but I cannot see us returning to this location.First, the good: Comfortable beds as you would expect in a Westin. Room was clean and the staff friendly when we arrived. We only stayed one night. Now the bad and the ugly:The trouble started when I called for a bellman to help with our bags. This was the last stop of a 10 day road trip so we had a lot of stuff with us. I called for a bellman while my wife took the kids downstairs to get the car from the valet. And I waited. And waited. Finally I called again after 20 minutes and they said someone would be right up. And I waited some more. And my wife called and said she could bring a cart up for me. Finally the bellman came THIRTY MINUTES after my first call. This was on a Monday morning at 10AM, not exactly abustle time. Unacceptable level of service, really ruined what would have been a great stay. Went from 4 stars to 3. Very disappointing.A really great hotel in a convenient location in downtown Columbus.You walk into a grand lobby that has the detail grandiose buildings used to have. Considering the building has been around since the late 1800s, it's in fantastic condition. I've been told that every room is different - ours was okay - kind of small, but that was very normal during the time these types of hotels were built. There's a bar, a restaurant, a business center (included with the hotel stay/no extra fees) and a small workout room. The hotel is a great location in downtown within walking distance to all the downtown sights as well as German Village.Overall, I had a good experience here, but staying inside such a historic building is what really made it worthwhile.This place is an embarrassment to the Westin brand - Service and food were great, but other than that, the physical facility is a joke. Room I was in had a bathroom that smelled moldy, parts of it had motel like wear and tear, and internet was slow speedtest.net/result/826.... I've seen better gyms at Courtyard Marriotts And who at AAA was asleep at the wheel when this place got 4 stars... absurd. There's a difference between a cool, restored historic hotel (Blackstone/Palmer House in Chicago, Liberty/Omni Parker in Boston, etc...) and an old hotel that a little money was thrown into in. Insult to the Westin brandMade my wedding day sooooo special! So my wedding was not located at the Westin at all. However I have always loved the lobby of this gorgeous hotel. So I contacted the Westin to obtain photography rights in the lobby. All they required was a one night stay, which was perfect because we wanted to find a room at a hotel away from our family and friends!! Due to money constraints we went with the Queen standard room! Well when my wedding day arrived it was 90 degrees outside and it rained for about 3 solid hours. Now not a little rain, all of my guests referred to it as a monsoon. So thank goodness we had the Westin to take pictures in, because the park was not happening obviously! Four about an hour my wedding party (10 of us) plus three photographers ran around the lobby and the second floor area taking pictures! It was soo fun! The hotel was so sweet when we returned at the end of the night, upgrading our room to suite. I did not realize they had until we were up in our room! The room was gorgeous and super clean! There were strawberries, chocolates and a bottle of champagne on the dresser. I figured one of our friends had surprised us, but no it was from the Westin. Such a cute surprise!!! This visit made me a loyal Starwood guest !!! This was 08/14/2010 The pictures turned out gorgeously!Built in 1897 (Southern Theater was built in 1896), The Westin Great Southern Hotel is a true landmark of Columbus! It is the only grand hotel (aside from Hotel Hartman which is now condos) still standing in Columbus. With its lavish lobbies and ballroom, Columbus is very proud to still have this jewel of the Gilded Age. Great for overnight visitors, conferences and events as well as weddings.It has hosted presidents and celebrities such as President McKinley and President Teddy Roosevelt to as recent as Hillary Clinton and President Obama. This is Clinton and Obama's hotel of choice while staying the night in Columbus. The hotel is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and is one of the National Trust Historic Hotels of America. I take some issue with some other reviews about the size of the rooms. This is an historic hotel built in the 1890s. The size of most rooms of that time are smaller and typical of the Victorian era. If you want a vast McMansion room (like other Westin hotels) this is not the hotel for you. However, if you want a truly elegant, first class room that has much history and luxury, you are in for a treat! The rooms are not small, they are very comfortable. Dogs welcomed! They also have an excellent staff and great restaurant. Thurber Bar is also a great place to hang out and have a few drinks. Check out the video about the hotel's history I made for Columbus Landmarks Foundation: youtube.com/watch?v=O8mR...The hotel was almost torn down many times during the 1960s through the 1980s. Fortunately, Marcus Hotel Group and Westin acquired the hotel and spent millions upon millions of dollars on historic restoration and modern amenities. Here's some more history:Columbus was abuzz on the hot summer night in 1897. The city's leaders had fulfilled their promise in building the "showcase of the midwest" and tonight, the 23rd of August, The Great Southern Fireproof Hotel and Opera House was opened to the public. It had been a tragic decade for hotels in this capitol city, with fires claiming the Seneca, the Deshler, and the Vendome Hotels. It was with great pride that the populace toured the majestic building, as it had been built on the dreams of 400 men investing $100 each towards its construction.They marveled at the spectacular lobby that had been designed with exquisite taste and admirable skill. The decorative work was treated in specially modeled plaster, the ceiling beams forming panels which housed spectacularly decorative stained glass, with the central panel forming a magnificent dome. Pink marble wainscoting was edged by appropriately designed woodwork of cherry, creating a color scheme between old gold and terra cotta.As visitors strolled through the peer of all lobbies, they roamed to the Cafe or supper room, lavatory, travelers' exchange (containing railroad, ticket, telegraph, transfer company and telephone offices), check rooms, bar, billiard, reading and writing rooms, barber shop, and in further wonder...five stores.Never before had some of the visitors seen such a fine example of French Renaissance architecture, and they marveled at the open aired feeling as they strolled the promenade on the second floor which was landed centrally either by the grand stairway or elevators.Directly connected with the promenade were spacious parlors with views of High Street, the main dining room, maids' dining room, ordinary (breakfast) room, private dining room and guest chamber corridor. The principal features of the second floor were the dining rooms and parlors with the balance devoted to the kitchen and guest chambers.The dining room itself was akin to a palace ballroom, and no expense had been spared in its construction. Local laborers stood by the city's elite as the general manager, J. M. Lee, welcomed them to the hotel. They marveled at the extreme size of the room, extending the height of the second and third floors at a total expanse of 46 x 90. The length, however, was masterly relieved by a decorative arch which screened and secluded the musician's gallery. With six fluted pilasters on each side and dome capitals surmounted by an ornate entendres, the dining room presented an appearance, second to none in the country.The parlors were finished in white enamel and gold with unique designs as more than a few ladies retired to the comfort of the seating arrangements away from the cigar smoke of the men.The Great Southern housed 222 guest rooms in its expanse, with two club rooms, 56 private bathrooms and 8 public baths. The guest chambers on the second, third, and fourth stories was finished in plain oak, while the balance was completed in yellow pine.Quite ahead of her time, the grand dame as she would soon be known housed the latest equipment for electric work, call bells, heating, ventilating and plumbing. Huge coal fired boilers were located in the basement which also housed the buildings own water supply.Normally, I wouldn't give a hotel the Westin's size and location a 5-Star rating, but their customer service was OUTSTANDING. Absolutely stellar!My husband and I live here in Columbus and have stayed at the Westin Columbus twice, both times for special occasions. They made us feel like royalty each time! We've decided that the Westin is now "our place" to go when we run away from home!Would give it zero stars. I've stayed in many Westin in the US and abroad. This is the worst and most disappointing. The rooms are tiny, and dirty. The bedding wAs course and the sheet barely fit over the bed. I could see the mattress. The bathroom has rust stains and grudgy. The room service was jus awful. No matter what I tell them, I always get 9 grain bread- when I ask for white toast or French toast! My coffee canister had curdled milk in it. I went to show the people at reception and they were like la dee dah. Never again. Awful. I'm so shocked Starwood would allow this Bc it's definitely not what I expect from a Starwood hotel.Beautiful lobby. Front desk had a bit of attitude which I didn't understand. Lobby bar was very nice and the bartender was friendly and knew the history of the place which was interesting. Now for the room. Our first room was the size of a cell. No design sense. No color. Drab and claustipobic. As we are preferred customers with Starwood we asked for an upgrade. Second room was twice the size but still nothing to make it welcoming. That being said, the bed was very comfortable. Also the air conditioning was not working correctly. Not what we expected from a Westin.I'm not a big hotel person bc I always feel like they're dirty...but this hotel was so nice! The beds are insane comfortable and the showers...awesome. Everyone has been super friendly, I would definitely stay here again!I checked in at the Westin Columbus for one night. I asked if there was a Starwood preferred floor. She said "No." In my experience, it's typical for Westin to have this. Then I asked about breakfast (last time I stayed here I was offered a complimentary breakfast) she said it wasn't in my room rate. (That's not what I asked, but ok). I asked another way and explained I got one before. She said that the person helping me was probably being nice. So naturally I asked her if she could be nice too. (Wouldn't you?!) She gave me the room key and was like "have a great night". I am a team leader at a large company and deal with clients all day. I felt she was not listening to me. So I said, "I just wanted to offer some feedback, when someone asks you a direct question it's appreciated if you respond with a direct answer because I don't feel like you were really listening to me about breakfast or the Starwood room" So, she says "thanks for telling me how to do my job!!!" and storms away. I was thinking...omg did that just really happen? Now I just can't walk away unless I get her name because that upset me so much. So I start saying "excuse me, excuse me" over and over with no response. Finally I asked a server who happened to be walking by to get the person behind the desk to come out to help me and I wanted to know her name. Another girl comes out and apologizes on her behalf which is totally unfair to that girl. I asked again about the Starwood room and she said they don't have a specific floor but there are rooms mixed in. The room I got was NOT one, I don't get that at all, perfect example of the not listening thing. So the second girl switched my room. Turns out the original girl was actually the manager! Not sure how to spell it, but the managers name was Elana. No one wanted to tell me her name until I asked several times, wonder why. I'm a huge believer in the fact that people make mistakes but this was crossing the line and totally unacceptable. She either needs to keep her personal life issues at home, get proper training on client service from Westin, or not work with people at all because under no circumstance is it ok to tell a guest who is offering feedback "thanks for telling me how to do my job." and cowardly storm off.This is not a Westin. It has the name of the hotel but if you compare it to ANY other ones you will be shocked.CONS:When asked if I could be upgraded to a king I was replied with a "sure for $20.00 more.' REALLY???? WOW. I passed.Hotel room was the SMALLEST to the point they have to put the tv on the wall...at an angle to fit in.DIRTY shower. There was residue ALL over the corners of the shower...I had to take one but stuck to the front portion. Didn't understand the whole dual shower head especially when there was a LARGE sign right above it stating not to use to "conserve water". Air conditoner did NOT work. We slept with it on at 66 no lie and still were hot- we were on the 6th floor and I get heat rises but really??The bar seemed overwhelmed- when I asked to order food he was like "really?" and then the amount you get for the price would make me hit the yellow pages if I was to stay there again.When I asked the concierge to bring up a personal item that I needed...they never came up. I had to go down to let them know I was leaving and just to leave it in the room. NOT IMPRESSED.Parking for $20 bucks in an open parking lot out back?????They are lucky my car was safely returned.PRO:Nice lobby but who stays in one? They don't even have couches/chairs so you can linger in it.PASS.PASS.PASS. Pay the extra $30 bucks and stay at the Renissance.The hotel is old and the rooms are small and dated. The door jamb and lock bar were literally falling off and the top of the bathroom door stuck so it was really loud when opening. We checked in around five in the afternoon and asked the front desk where a good place to eat would be and were told the hotel has a very nice restaurant but we never found out because when we went down to eat we were told the restaurant only opens for breakfast and lunch and is closed for dinner. Very odd. Goofed and forgot to pack my tooth brush so I called the front dest for a complimentary one that every hotel has, they didn't. Had toothpaste, no brushes. For a hotel that charges $149 for a small dingy room, $22 for parking, $10 for Internet you'd sure think they could manage to keep those little 5 cent toothbrushes. Oh and one last negative- the hotel staff picking up dishes from the hallway from anyone having room service the night before, does not seem to care one bit that you might want to sleep past 7a.m. because they are extremely loud with their work and outdoor voice conversations. The bed however was quite comfy. (Until about 7 a.m.)I've noticed in the negative reviews that Phil B. replies asking what he can do and telling reviewers to contact him and he will make sure the next visit is as it should be. Why can't the service and quality be there the first time we pay? Fool me once...
review_content_80: I was in town for the Columbus Half Marathon. I wanted something quiet where I could rest and focus on the race so was only considering upscale hotels. Booked on Priceline using "name your own price", and got the Westin for $70/night.I got to the hotel, and found out that they also had a wedding planned on Saturday, the night before the race. I was a little afraid that it was going to be loud (it's an old hotel, after all), but they were advising all guests that they needed to be quiet in the rooms. Not only did they mention it at check-in, they also reminded all guests about it by slipping little reminder notes under their door. They also made run that the marathon participants were in one section of the hotel where they wouldn't be as disturbed. The room itself was ridiculously tiny. There was a bed, two night stands. The bed was very comfortable, and the shower was excellent. But there was not even a desk. I understand that they are going to give me the smallest rooms when I get a deal on price line, but what kind of top rated hotel does not even offer a desk? I was planning to do some work after the race on Sunday, and had to go sit in a coffee shop. The service was ok. The bartender in the restaurant was quite unfriendly and rushed me, which was even more surprising given that I was the only customer at the time and it wasn't even near her closing time. The rest of the staff was nice, but not especially helpful. When I asked them about the closest Tim Horton's, one of them looked up directions for a Tim Horton half a mile away. The place had been close for 6 months... half-mile away, they should have known. The other employee kept on trying to convince me that I should try their in-house starbucks instead, and wasn't interested at all into helping me find a Tim Horton's. I also had to pay $25 for an in-room breakeast a 5:30 (only option available for me before the race), and the breakfast consisted of a bagel, coffee and a cup of not so fresh berries.With respect to the location, there was major construction (demolition) in the area, and other than that it was completely dead. The hotel is about 1mile from nationwide arena, and a 2-3 minute was to Broad and Third (where the race started). The location was perfect for what I wanted.Overall, I would say that I would not have been happy if I had paid $170 for the room that I got. Yet, at $70, I was pleased. I got a very comfortable bed, good location, and peace to rest for the race. But the service and the room wasn't exactly up to what you'd expect from a luxury hotel. Try to get a deal on priceline.Why this place has so many good reviews is beyond me. I have stayed in many many luxury hotels all over the world as well as more standard levels and I think my assessment here is more than fair. I had never been to Columbus before and checked all the reviews for the four star hotels in the area (they don't have any five stars) -- all the hotels had mixed reviews but the Westin seemed to have the more consistent positive reviews on TripAdvisor and Yelp so I took a gamble. Cons: -Everyone raves about the lobby...I've seen better, it's not that big a deal...I'm guessing if you've never stayed in a "fancy" hotel or you're from the mid-west this probably seems luxurious. Trust me, it's not. It's nice, but it's nothing stellar. -Low floors. Most buildings in Columbus seem to be short of stature and this was no exception topping out at the 6th floor. -Dark with no view. I had booked a King size suite which was small and cramped with three windows overlooking the parking lot. It also barely got any light. I was on the 3rd floor. -The bathroom was smaller than the one in my NYC apartment. -They don't have a press in their laundry so the bed linens (even the "clean" ones) were constantly wrinkled giving the appearance that they had not been laundered.-Housekeeping was not thorough...they barely cleaned the room, the bathroom was only 1/2 done (but they were more than happy to swipe the generous cash tip I left for them on the bed).-As it is a small hotel there doesn't seem to be a real dedicated "room service" kitchen but you can order from one of the on-site restaurant menus...the menu in the room was printed on plain copy paper and was dated two years ago -- I ordered scrambled eggs for breakfast one morning but didn't eat anything else from their food service because it didn't seem very appetizing. -Location: here is what is around your hotel....two court houses, a jail, and a bail bonds office. Really charming atmosphere. Also, you can't walk to anything good. The Easton shopping (which seems to be the most Columbus has to offer, aside from the Zoo and the Whistle factory) was a $40 cab ride away. Pros: -It's cheap. A king size suite for two nights only cost me around $500. -The valet was very good. -It was close to the airport. -When I complained to the front desk that my room hadn't been cleaned properly and that one of the window shades had fallen down they sent up a manager who had the shade fixed immediately, and agreed that the cleaning was sloppy and had the bathroom cleaned again (though the maid did a substandard job the second time around too)Overall, I would not recommend this hotel to anyone planning on staying in Columbus. If I go back again, I will look into other hotels in the area.Stayed at Westin Columbus last weekend while in Columbus for a date night. We were so surprised at what we got for the relatively small amount we paid! The hotel staff was very friendly. The room was great with really comfy beds. Also, the workout room was pretty awesome. Will stay again.This is supposed to be a 4 star hotel. The only thing about it that is, is the name on the building and the lobby. The rooms are old and dirty. The service was poor. I travel at least every month and always stay in 4 star hotels. This location is a disappointment to the Westin name. AVOID this hotel.I stayed at this property for four nights during a recent business trip. The hotel is located slightly on the outskirts of the downtown region, though it was still within (longer) walking distance to everything. The hotel has a grand, old feel to it upon entering the marble adorned foyer. The desk was staffed by three attractive women who promptly checked-in and out customers. Even though I had arrived a few minutes prior to 11pm, I was told that regular food service for the evening was over and I was limited to the overnight menu which consisted of a poor selection of food at exorbitant prices. I arrived at my room and was shocked at how incredibly small it was. I stay in hotels 100+ nights a year and have never experienced a room as tight as this one (~160 sq ft). It consisted of a large king bed (which took up most of the room, a nearby desk, tv and similarly tiny bathroom and miniscule closet. I was honestly shocked that as a Platinum guest, I would be placed in such a room. I initially decided to deal with it but quickly felt very cramped for space. I called the front desk and spoke with a manager about a possible room change. I was told the hotel was almost completely booked but he could place me in an accessible room which would be larger. I graciously accepted. The manager appeared at my door promptly with a new set of keys and apologized for the inconvenience. He mentioned that the hotel was modeled after European boutique hotels, thus explaining why the rooms were so cramped. I told him I was appalled that I would not have been upgraded to an accessible room or similarly larger room prior to arrival and he again apologized. The new room was about the size of a typical room. It consisted of the same basic amenities but with breathing room between getting out of bed and walking to the bathroom. I was disappointed that the shower did not have the typical dual showerhead but I got over it quickly because I was thankful for the additional space. I ate breakfast in the hotel restaurant every morning and was pleasantly surprised by the excellent meal options. I became rather addicted to their breakfast tacos with deli turkey, salsa, peppers, onions, avocado and fresh fruit. The service was attentive and I was lucky enough to receive the same people every day. My one major complaint, which isn't directly caused by the hotel, but more so with the city of Columbus is the horrible taxi service. Because the weather was hot and humid, and my office was several blocks away, I opted for cab service. Unfortunately, even though the cab advertised that it took credit cards, on almost every occasion, I was told credit cards were not accepted which continually put me in a bind because I rarely carry any cash. Overall every taxi driver I experienced in Columbus was rude, unprofessional and their vehicles were disgusting on the inside. From now on, I'll be renting a car.Overall I had a pleasant stay at the hotel but the distance to city life and tiny rooms, leave a lot to be desired. Unless the nearby Hyatt is sold out, I don't plan on returning.Friendly staff, very nice lobby (southern style). Good food in their Thurber's bar and a pretty well equipped gym. The staff remember you and are genuinely nice.Beautiful place to meet the top organizations in Columbus serving our great community! Very good meeting rooms and atmosphere, really enjoyed the event because of the good location and venue. Looking forward to a get-away night here in the future!I thought this hotel was fantastic overall. I stayed here for a couple of nights and attended a wedding reception held in one of their halls (errr.. might be their only hall?). First off our room was great. The pillows and sheets were sooo comfy. The robes were nice and huge (great since the towels never fit around me.. beh). The desk had 3 outlets on the front of it, which was awesome (usually you have to do some crawling or moving of furniture to find outlets). The flat screen TV was pretty cool, but a little moody (and $11 for movies? WHA?) so it'd go from quiet to loud with different commercials. Kind of lame that the internet was $10 a day considering I've stayed at cheaper hotels with free internet. Nice water pressure in the shower.. but what's up with the double shower heads? I never could figure them out. Two main peeves? The air conditioner beeps constantly when changing temperature and I had to do the jiggly thing with the toilet handle. Classy.Brunch was great and served in the mezzanine. I'll be honest and say I don't know if this is a regular thing or was special for the wedding party. There were these cinnamony cake things that were heavenly and the cuts of meat for the sandwiches were very tasty. The reception hall was so lovely. I know the couple had a wedding planner sort things out, but the atmosphere with the windows and the general room were so elegant. One thing is this place is FREEZING.. so make sure to dance your tushy off on the dance floor! Great acoustics by the way.. I heard this place was once a theater? I could definitely tell. The Westin salad with the raspberry vinaigrette (I love goat cheese and sun dried tomatoes) and the crab cake & chicken plate were very good. Much love to their mashed potatoes.. totally hit the spot. The bathroom that was by the reception hall was amazing. It was clean throughout the night and just generally schmancy. In the ladies room they had baskets of whatever you might need.. hairspray, gum, lotion, sanitary products, sprays, etc. No worries if you couldn't fit your 5 oz. of beauty product on your plane ride over or in that tiny clutch you decided to bring. The workers were generally nice, although the ones I passed in the hallway were mum. And the woman at the desk gave us the wrong time for mass. Oh well. The servers at the reception/brunch, however, were ridiculously on their game. They all seriously seemed like they really loved what they did. I would have tipped them all individually if I had the money. And the same servers that chatted with us during the cocktail hour, followed up with us during the reception. I would definitely come back and stay here if I were in the area or suggest it as an event hotel (the Live Strong conference was either coming or going when we were here as well).I was only going to Columbus for one night, so I kind of had to make the hotel count.I settled on the Westin based on the overall price and of course the general Yelp consensus...The hotel, as mentioned, has just gone through a major renovation and sports 7 floors of nicely appointed rooms in an older, stylish building. The size of my room reminded me of the one I had at the Soho Grand in New York -- large by NYC standards, but certainly on the smaller side for Columbus, I imagine. Regardless, it was plenty big for just me, and the special touches in the room made up for it.I'm not a hotel loyalist, generally, but I could certainly get used to the Heavenly Bed they have -- I really love a good comforter and some nice sheets in addition to the mattress -- and their own line of soaps and other toiletries is really nice too.Check out the photo I have up of the double shower head. That thing was mind bending, and perhaps a bit unnecessary and over the top, but made you feel like they at least tried to do something special with the shower.Great, thick white cotton robe in the closet, flat screen LCD TV and comfortable, muted tones in the room plus a complete mini-bar.Suggested improvements? 1) get rid of that retarded old transistor clock radio and get something with a digital signal or something you could plug your iPod into and 2) how about a free bottle of water? $5? Yeah. No.Other than that, a great stay and super close to M -- see my review yelp.com/biz/m-restauran.... I'd definitely stay here again.The Westin was an okay hotel - definitely not a luxury hotel by any means. My stay here was a Hotwire booking, which is probably why I found myself in a tiny room on the second floor with a commanding view of a brick wall. What bothered me more than anything about being on this floor was that the second floor was half-guest rooms and half banquet/meeting rooms. During my stay, there was a huge wedding going on, and the party lasted well into the night. Surely there were rooms available on one of the numerous other floors?!The hotel's gym was impressive - large, with a variety of machines, free weights and cardio. It was 24 hour, and since I wasn't part of the wedding party going on on my floor, I got a late-night workout with the gym all to myself. Parking was pricey and valet - in my opinion, parking on the street in that part of Columbus would be taking a risk with your car. Not much more to the hotel than that. The hotel was definitely a big, historic one, but I didn't really feel its charm.Awesome historic hotel, SUPER comfortable beds, close to cool restaurants/bars on High St, and very tasty Angus burger available until 11pm in the lounge. (I had it twice!)The staff was exceptional during my visit. The front desk staff was very courteous and extremely accommodating, and everyone that helped with the conference room was very professional, helpful and fun. My company strives to create a professional atmosphere for our customers during our trainings, and the training that I did at The Westin Columbus was perfect. The wait staff and all who helped set up our training room were very responsive to my requests for assistance. I found them to be extremely friendly and totally cool. I enjoyed working with everyone with whom I interacted at The Westin Columbus.I also wanted to say that I truly appreciated the program (I can't remember its name) that enabled me to forego room cleaning in favor of the $5 vouchers that can be used in the restaurant or lounge. I'm very interested in conservation, "going green" or whatever you might call it, but the reward of the daily voucher is really a nice touch!Thanks for everything!Located in the heart of downtown Columbus, the Westin is an historic hotel with one of the most spectacular lobbies you'll ever see. The rooms are small, but the bathrooms are updated (and twin shower heads). Every room has a flat screen TV. The basement gym has all the equipment you'll need for a solid workout. A winner!Nice hotel, good location, nice staff - the door man and front desk staff were very kind. The beds are extremely comfortable. On the other hand, the rooms are small and there aren't many outlets/plugs in the rooms. The bathroom sink was really small. Plus, rooms are high priced for the accomodations...and internet is not included.The Westin Columbus is a beautiful old 100+ year old hotel. The stately, high-ceilinged lobby, oozing with wood, leather, marble and stained glass is from another era; just walking in to it makes you feel good and special, to have somehow merited that kind of a welcome, in a way that all the world's W's, with their ambient trance music and subdued lounge lighting will never be able to match.Not to sell it short, but that lobby may be the best thing about the Westin --it is, after all, an older hotel, so the rooms are on the small side. The walls are also paper thin: I was able to hear the ex-frat boys next door, apparently in town for a fellow d-bag's wedding, talking about groping unsuspecting girls in bars, and wrestling with each other after their morning showers, all while I was trying to sleep off a Sunday morning hangover. They weren't being overly loud, even for d-bags --it's just that the walls were that thin. The bathroom had nice, modern fixtures and fluffy towels, but was lit as dimly as one of the W Hotel lobbies contrasted above. Also, there was no place to set your toiletries down, and I'm just a guy with a shaving kit --someone traveling with more product would probably end up having to just lay them out on the floor.I've stayed here a number of times, and sometimes you'll get a bigger room than the one I described above, but bottom line is, you're getting the old school charm of an old school hotel, along with the old school accommodations. Still, I'll stay here again because I love just walking into the place, and the rates are usually pretty decent. Would've given it 4 stars based on all that, but I'm knocking one off because they charge for in-room wi-fi, which in this day and age is like charging for tap water.Historic hotel is extremely clean and charming - with granite/marble throughout. Hotel staff - from valet to front desk to the corporate office - is friendly, helpful, and professional. Having stayed here for three consecutive weeks, I enjoy the varying room layouts of an historic building - which is atypical from the standard cookie cutter rooms of many other hotels. Highly recommend.So as mentioned in other reviews, I'm a Starwood addict and I generally find Westins more consistent than Sheratons. And I like their beds better. So this one is no exception in that regard. Had a nice lobby.I checked in here shortly after becoming a gold member and I got upgraded to a suite which was only the second time I'd been upgraded to a suite, BUT the suite had a window that looked out on a wall. So it was really dark and sort of depressing, but it looks like most of the rooms don't have this problem.I've never actually stayed here, but I've been here for a few events and it always makes you feel classy. It has that charm from a time when materials and labor were cheap enough to do everything on a grand scale. Not that it's ridiculously huge or anything, just nice and classy. Not sure what the rooms are like, but the staff is always nice and helpful. If I was an out of towner, I would love to stay here.Wow, I'm on a four-star roll. This wasn't the best Westin I've ever stayed at. Sometimes the soap or the robe was missing, and the key stopped working if you placed it anywhere near your wallet. There were sometimes various little issues with the room. Not big enough to matter, but big enough to annoy me and knock it down to a 4-star rating.BUT, what they lacked in 5-star luxury they made up for in personality. The staff are phenomenal - quick to correct a mistake and they always remember your name if you're a regular. I had people saying "Hi Archita, how are you today" that I didn't even recognize. Insane. When you're forced to travel to Columbus, staying at this Westin makes all the difference. Plus, I started getting ridiculous upgrades, apology letters and free drinks when an upgrade wasn't available, and personalized gift baskets based on things I liked. Not all Starwoods are anywhere as meticulous as that. (Sometimes the level of gifting was inconsistent though, which made me sad :( but dude...am I really even complaining about this?) Also, who doesn't love a Westin - any Westin? Their "heavenly" bed and double-showerhead is enough to convince me to fork over an extra $40 (expensed to the company, of course, haha) for the stay. If you get a chance to eat at their restaurant, ORDER THE CRAB CAKES! Amazing. Yalumba is a great white wine to pair with that.I've stayed at a lot of very nice hotels before (trump, banff fairfield - gold level), so I may be biased. Although this isn't the worst, I do feel that there are some things they can improve upon. They don't give you enough coffee packs for even two people. 1 pack is not enough for 2 people to drink. Heck, even 2 packs aren't enough for hardcore french press drinkers. Every day, I have consistently not had hot water when I have wanted to either wash my face or take a shower. They did give us a nice suite upgrade which I appreciate, but I still want a hot shower when I'd like to take one! Seriously, morning and night, I've had to wait a considerable amount of time before I could even get enough hot water to wash my face. I've been going around smelly, after the gym, until the afternoon when the hot water has regenerated. Luckily no one else has to be around me right now. There is no room service menu. In the folder where they try to sell you the linens, there's an empty spot but no one has even noticed the lack of a food menu. Others are ordering room service around me yet I am doomed to take my lazy butt downstairs. haha. Their gym is shoved downstairs in the basement. Although it is small, they have a nice collection of work out equipment from several treadmills, circuit machines, dumbbells, benches, pilates balls, resistance bands, etc. Whoever cleans the gym has not realized that they are out of water. It's so frustrating to go to the water cooler after a hard workout, and it's empty. Housekeeping barely does enough. They don't even empty out the ice bucket from the water left over from the previous night's ice. When they replace towels, they don't hang them nicely like the first night, they just stack them up on top. They don't always wipe off the lacquered coffee table in the suite room. They throw the used robe on top of a chair instead of nicely hung up in the closet or bathroom. I asked for extra coffee for the room, and I was handed one extra pack for this morning's coffee. After they cleaned our room, we still had only 1 pack replenished and the one that I had to ask for. Good customer service would be where they automatically give us more than 1 pack (and not just once) after being asked. Again, these are all small things. Not deal breakers, but if we were paying, I'd be getting a refund.The most comfortable bed that I have ever slept on, beautiful bathrooms (dual-headed shower!), and a really classy looking building. This place was everything you could expect from a hotel in Columbus.Would have given it 4 stars but I was handed a glass of champagne when I checked in. That deserves a gold star sticker! Oh, and at $80 a night for two people on a weekend (hotwire.com), you're way affordable too.Thumbs up, Westin-Columbus, you're 5-star certified!
